I’m relatively new to it, if anyone has experience with it and can look over what I’ve done, that would be appreciated simple_smile#2016-01-0602:02danielcomptonI’m thinking of separating out the clojars site build from the deploy phase, especially as this is likely to be run when the officials clojars repo is down#2016-01-0602:03danielcomptonSo the Clojars uberjar will get built (by the Clojars server?) and put on S3, and then any future ansible run will be able to pull it down without clojars needing to be up#2016-01-0602:04danielcomptonI ran into a humorous issue where i had set the hostname of the vagrant box to be http://clojars.org so it tried to look up itself to download dependencies when the box was bootstrapping#2016-01-0602:09tcrawleyha#2016-01-0602:09tcrawleyhmm, yeah, I guess it is kind of odd that we we build clojars on clojars, requiring clojars#2016-01-0602:10tcrawleywe could also build the uberjar locally, then copy it to the server#2016-01-0602:10tcrawleyand have the build run the tests first#2016-01-0602:10tcrawleyas it does now#2016-01-0602:14danielcomptonyeah that would be good, but I think it might need to be a separate operation so that if clojars is down it can still be redeployed#2016-01-0602:14tcrawleywell, if we move the repo to block storage, the repo would still be available, as would the mirror#2016-01-0602:15danielcomptonThinking about pricing for cloud storage, do you know how the request pattern works with Leiningen when looking for deps? My assumption is that it checks custom repos, Maven Central, then Clojars. I wonder if we pay for requests for resources that don’t exist?#2016-01-0602:16danielcomptonThere won’t be much bandwidth, but there is a per request fee which might add up if there are lots of 404s?#2016-01-0602:16tcrawleythat's a good point - yeah, aether asks everyone for everything, so we get lots of 404s#2016-01-0602:17tcrawleywe should check to make sure providers don't charge for 404 requests#2016-01-0602:17tcrawleybrb#2016-01-0602:17danielcomptongotta go too#2016-01-0603:00danielcomptonhttps://forums.aws.amazon.com/thread.jspa?messageID=58436#2016-01-0603:01danielcompton> As our intent is to charge equitably for system resources used, we will be charging the owner of the bucket for 403s and 404s, since they consume system resources (as do all requests). Note that we will not be charging for requests which fail due to an Amazon S3 internal system error (all other requests will be billed).#2016-01-0603:04tcrawleyinteresting#2016-01-0603:08danielcomptonMight be good to use multiple dns providers too https://medium.com/@brianarmstrong/youre-probably-doing-dns-wrong-like-we-were-6625efaed390#.eu8hcul6c#2016-01-0603:56tcrawleythat's an interesting read. I wonder if DNSimple has since added support for multiple providers?#2016-01-0603:56tcrawleywe'll see soon enough I guess#2016-01-0604:45tcrawleythey have: files, as they will prevent a deploy from working at all once they are atomic#2016-01-0717:47tcrawleyso we need a tool to scan the repo and find/fix them#2016-01-0717:47tcrawleyI'll file an issue for that#2016-01-0717:47michasounds like a plan#2016-01-0717:48tcrawleyassuming we signal on the maven-metadata.xml being uploaded to know when a deployment is complete#2016-01-0717:48michaperhaps we can scan on deploy, too#2016-01-0717:48michaand then whitelist known good repos#2016-01-0717:48tcrawleyand I don't know how else to signal#2016-01-0717:49tcrawleywell, aether won't even give us a maven-metadata.xml if it is invalid, since it will pull the existing, see that its checksum is wrong, and bail#2016-01-0717:50tcrawleythat's really what I mean by "invalid"#2016-01-0717:50michai see#2016-01-0717:50tcrawleythough the checksums could be correct, it just doesn't list all the versions (or extra versions if there has been a deletion)#2016-01-0717:50tcrawleysince our deletion process doesn't currently fix the metadata#2016-01-0717:51michayeah tests cases will help here#2016-01-0717:51tcrawleywho do I talk to to get the github plugin running in this channel?#2016-01-0717:51michawe could, in theory, automate metadata.xml fixing, right?#2016-01-0717:52tcrawleyyes#2016-01-0717:52michalike given a repo with poms we can generate a good metadata file#2016-01-0717:52michaso maybe that's the first step#2016-01-0717:53tcrawleyright, I see it as a fn that we run as part of a scan now, then right after deploying the atomic deploys feature, then on specific repos when we delete a version#2016-01-0717:53tcrawleyonce atomic deploys are there, we shouldn't need to scan again#2016-01-0717:53tcrawleyin theory#2016-01-0717:53tcrawleyfiling an issue atomically#2016-01-0718:06michalol it would be ironic if a race condition causes the tool to corrupt metadata#2016-01-0718:06michaso i'll look and try to see what the best way to do that will be#2016-01-0718:07michamaybe it has to run during a deploy, the update part where it molests the metadata file#2016-01-0718:08tcrawleywe currently don't mutate the metadata at all, aether does that#2016-01-0718:08tcrawleyif aether doesn't download the metadata until after it has started the deploy, we could fix this on the fly#2016-01-0718:08michayeah but someone could be deploying while we're fixing their metadata#2016-01-0718:09tcrawleyah, true#2016-01-0718:10tcrawleyif we detect a deploy is happening, we could fix the metadata as soon as we see the first artifact (before sending a response to that request)#2016-01-0718:10michayep#2016-01-0718:10tcrawleybut only if aether doesn't download it first#2016-01-0718:10michai haven't looked at the details of the server code either#2016-01-0718:12michabecause then you have a race between pulling metadata and deploying#2016-01-0718:12tcrawleythe repo is all served via nginx as static files, so we don't know in the app when See https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/415#2016-01-1018:07tcrawleyI had to disable it for https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/424 as well#2016-01-1018:08shanekilkellyah, I see. I thought it meant that promotion was currently broken, so i thought my new library wasn’t available, turns out it’s all working fine#2016-01-1018:08tcrawleywere you using the releases repo?#2016-01-1018:08tcrawleyyeah, that's part of the confusion around promotion - it's a common misunderstanding that it is required for the artifact to be available#2016-01-1018:09shanekilkellyi was totally under the impression it was essential#2016-01-1018:09tcrawleywhen an artifact deploys successfully, it's available in the primary repo immediately#2016-01-1018:09shanekilkellyanyway, I can see why you’re removing it simple_smile#2016-01-1018:10tcrawleypromotion is only to move it to the releases repo, which is a failed experiment#2016-01-1018:10tcrawleysorry for the confusion#2016-01-1018:10shanekilkellyit’s cool, all good#2016-01-1018:10tcrawleyI need to accelerate getting rid of it#2016-01-1021:39danielcomptonhttps://web.archive.org/web/20150219021408/http://clojars.com/#2016-01-1021:39tcrawleyinteresting!#2016-01-1021:39tcrawleyI wonder why that person never got in touch with us?#2016-01-1023:02danielcomptonyeah, it’s a shame#2016-01-1114:16tcrawley@danielcompton: there are probably gaps in the 404s in the logs - I added log_not_found off; the the nginx config for /repo at some point, since we didn't have the disk space for large logs#2016-01-1114:17tcrawleyI re-enabled it a few days ago#2016-01-1114:17tcrawleybut not in the ansible config. fixing that#2016-01-1114:20tcrawleyhmm. What we need most atm is PRs for issues. we've been given plenty of money, but don't have time to fix everything that needs fixing#2016-01-1314:30meowreally#2016-01-1314:30meowhrm#2016-01-1314:30meowtell me more#2016-01-1314:30meowso I can get on that and find some help#2016-01-1314:52tcrawleywe have a list of issues "ready for work" at https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/labels/ready#2016-01-1314:53tcrawleythere are probably a few more that have come in recently that should be tagged with :ready as well#2016-01-1315:00meowok, I will review them to see if I can think of how to get volunteers to help with them#2016-01-1315:01tcrawleygreat, thanks!#2016-01-1315:02tcrawleysorry for the quick responses, I'm just swamped with work stuff atm.#2016-01-1315:03meowI understand#2016-01-1315:55micha@meow: i want to work on a tool that can detect and fix broken maven metadata xml files#2016-01-1315:55michathis is needed before atomic commits can be implemented#2016-01-1315:55meowok#2016-01-1315:56meowso what do we need - some kind of parse of xml that can handle misformed xml or something#2016-01-1315:57meowsomething that validates maven metadata xml or more generic#2016-01-1315:57michait has to do with what happens on partial commits#2016-01-1315:58michalike when you push a release to the repo there are multiple artifacts that need to be uploaded#2016-01-1315:58michafoo-1.2.3.pom, foo-1.2.3.pom.asc, foo-1.2.3.jar, etc#2016-01-1315:58michaand it's possible that something fails before uploading all of them#2016-01-1315:59michathere is a metadata file that describes all the versions, which can get out of sync with the actual files in the repo#2016-01-1316:00michaso currently you can download jars from repos that don't have those versions listed in the metadata.xml file#2016-01-1316:00michabecause the jars made it into the repo but the metadata didn't#2016-01-1316:01michathe idea for atomic deploys, as i understand it, is to use the metadata.xml file to commit a transaction#2016-01-1316:01michaso the release won't be live until all artifacts have been uploaded and verified according to metadata.xml#2016-01-1316:51meowatomic commits is the goal then#2016-01-1316:53meowmetadata.xml is needed to commit an atomic transaction#2016-01-1316:56meowclarify for me: isn't a metadata file referencing versions that are out of sync a problem independent of atomic commits?#2016-01-1316:56meowand a missing metadata.xml file is the ultimate in borken#2016-01-1316:59meow@micha: how would you like to proceed? what's the first step? what can I do to help?#2016-01-1317:22gjnoonanHey all#2016-01-1317:29meowhey#2016-01-1318:16tcrawley@meow: correct - bad metadata is its own problem, but needs to be fixed before atomic deploys can be implemented#2016-01-1318:43meowgotcha#2016-01-1320:31meow@jonahbenton: any suggestions?#2016-01-1320:57jonahbentonsounds like @micha has the right of it. for problems like this i like approaches like https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/226#issuecomment-142270596. having the same tool be able to handle an atomic move from a dmz-like upload area to the canonical coordinates, as well as be able to validate/clean/fix artifacts within the canonical tree, probably makes sense. the plan is to continue to keep the repo on a file system?#2016-01-1321:19tcrawley@jonahbenton: the plan is to move the repo off to a cloud file store in the near future#2016-01-1321:19tcrawleybut that could be the last step in the verify pipeline#2016-01-1321:23jonahbenton@tcrawley: cool. so a tool that verified a group of file system resources for correctness and also delivered an atomic move of said resources to cloud could be utilized to populate the cloud file store with verified artifacts from the current repo, and also handle new artifact uploads going forward?#2016-01-1321:33tcrawley@jonahbenton: everything in the current repo will end up in the cloud store, correct or not, though we will run a tool across the repo to fix what we can before hand#2016-01-1512:24meow💌 for clojars and @tcrawley#2016-01-1719:35danielcompton@tcrawley: I moved the logo used in the SFC application to https://clojars.org/images/clojars-logo@2x.png#2016-01-1719:36tcrawleyah, right. no worries. I'll make a copy at the url I sent them#2016-01-1719:36tcrawleyhow are you this fine day?#2016-01-1719:36tcrawleywell, it's fine here at least :)#2016-01-1719:36danielcomptonback to work, which feels like a relief after looking after Jack over the weekend#2016-01-1719:36danielcomptonsimple_smile#2016-01-1719:36tcrawleyheh#2016-01-1719:36tcrawleyI've forgotten what that's like, thankfully :)#2016-01-1719:48tcrawleyI just added a redirect for the image to the nginx config:#2016-01-1719:48tcrawley

    return 301

#2016-01-1719:51danielcomptongreat#2016-01-1809:39oskarthAnyone know why postgresql 9.4 isn't available on Clojars? https://clojars.org/search?q=postgresql#2016-01-1812:45juhoteperi@oskarth: Because it's available in Maven Central: https://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails%7Corg.postgresql%7Cpostgresql%7C9.4.1207.jre7%7Cbundle#2016-01-1812:49juhoteperiHmm, postgresql driver being available at all on clojars is a bit suspicious. Especially the on with postgresql/postgresql coordinates which is same as old Maven Central coordinates.#2016-01-1813:44oskarth@juhoteperi: ah, makes sense. The discrepancy is what got me#2016-01-1819:39danielcomptonyeah, it is a bit weird, https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/468 should help fix this#2016-01-1819:39danielcomptonalthough I’m not sure what we do about existing projects#2016-01-1819:40tcrawleythat's something we'd need to discuss - should we purge existing projects that shadow stuff on central? we should determine how many shadowing projects we have#2016-01-1819:41tcrawleyor do we remove it only if the artifacts aren't identical?#2016-01-1819:42danielcomptonor the other way around, purge identical ones, and keep non identical ones?#2016-01-1819:42tcrawleyfor example, dynapath is on both clojars https://clojars.org/org.tcrawley/dynapath and central https://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails%7Corg.tcrawley%7Cdynapath%7C0.2.3%7Cjar#2016-01-1819:43tcrawleywell, if they are non-identical, we really don't want them there at all, since that would mean foo/bar 1.0 from clojars is different from foo/bar 1.0 from central, and central should probably be canon#2016-01-1819:43danielcomptonI guess, though it would be changing things people depend on#2016-01-1819:43danielcomptonIt would be nice to just purge them all#2016-01-1819:45tcrawleyI think if they are using foo/bar 1.0 from clojars when it exists on central, we have no way to know if the one on clojars is malicious#2016-01-1819:45tcrawleyand getting one over the other would depend on how the tooling ordered the lookup, possibly based on the order of the repos#2016-01-1819:46tcrawleybut I agree, if we purge, we should purge all#2016-01-1819:47juhoteperiBoot does ordered lookup, but I think it looks up clojars before central 😕#2016-01-1819:48juhoteperiOr at least Boot keeps the defined order and passes that to aether#2016-01-1820:28danielcompton

#2016-01-1820:57danielcomptonthat’s the complete list of duplicate groups#2016-01-1820:57danielcompton(not necessarily duplicate artifacts though, I didn’t check for that)#2016-01-1820:58danielcomptonactually, there’s a few more to check#2016-01-1821:06danielcomptonnope, that’s the list#2016-01-1821:12tcrawleyhow are you generating that list? because org.tcrawley should definitely be in it#2016-01-1901:20danielcompton
(ns central-lookup.core
  (require [org.httpkit.client :as http]
           [cheshire.core :as json]))

(def lines (read-string (slurp "groups.txt")))

(defn lookup-group [group]
  (try
    (-> @(http/get (format "" group))
        :body
        (json/parse-string))
    (catch Exception e
      true)))

(defn exists-in-central? [group]
  (-> (lookup-group group)
      (get-in ["response" "numFound"])
      (pos?)))

(def central-mem (memoize exists-in-central?))

(defn filter-in-clojars [xs]
  (filter central-mem xs))

Thanks for the help.#2016-02-0420:20tcrawleymy pleasure!#2016-02-0420:22juhoteperi@arrdem: project settings -> environment variables, though I use separate creds for CI#2016-02-0420:45arrdem@juhoteperi: yeah I'm doing some digging in the name of paranoia, trying to figure out if I can use Maven encrypted values in combination with environment variables. I've got this vision of a malicious PR that echos env vars 😐#2016-02-0420:45juhoteperiAt least in Circle CI, PR's don't see env variables#2016-02-0420:46juhoteperiOh right and you can define encrypted vars in travis.yml, and they wont be available in PRs#2016-02-0420:46arrdemsure but it'd be easy enough to write a PR containing code that does (println (System/getEnv "THE_PASSWORD_VAR_FROM_THE_CFG_FILES"))#2016-02-0420:46juhoteperiBut then you need to commit the encrypted value to repo#2016-02-0420:46juhoteperiBut the env variables are not at all set for PR builds in Circle#2016-02-0420:47juhoteperiLooks like env vars in Travis settings are available to all builds#2016-02-0420:48juhoteperiBut this looks good: https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/environment-variables/#Encrypting-Variables-Using-a-Public-Key#2016-02-0420:50arrdemhttps://circleci.com/docs/environment-variables#setting-environment-variables-for-all-commands-without-adding-them-to-git#2016-02-0420:50arrdemI meant circleci earlier not travis#2016-02-0420:50arrdemsorry#2016-02-0420:50arrdemlooks like the circle folk don't support such a thing#2016-02-0420:52juhoteperihttps://circleci.com/docs/fork-pr-builds#security-implications-of-running-builds-for-pull-requests-from-forks#2016-02-0420:53juhoteperiI have just configured the creds via web ui#2016-02-0420:53arrdemoh nice#2016-02-0420:53arrdemok well that solves that problem then#2016-02-0421:23danielcomptonJust pushed IMO that would be a huge and standardized benefit to the Clojure community. I understand it would be a fair amount of work.#2016-03-0420:51adamfreyas an example, the elm packages site: https://package.elm-lang.org/#2016-03-0422:23arrdemGrimoire internally has a documentation engine capable of this, but I've never taken the next step of generating docs on jar push.#2016-03-0422:23arrdemThis actually came up on my ideas list a few days ago. The only infrastructure I'd need is a way to get artifact coordinates when they're pushed.#2016-03-0422:24arrdemA short shell script wrapping https://github.com/clojure-grimoire/lein-grim would probably be all you needed beyond such a webhook.#2016-03-0506:40danielcomptonIt's a great idea, feel free to open an issue for it. I think everything is being uploaded to Clojars correctly? Any thoughts?#2016-03-2006:21chrisoakmanCould it have something to do with pom.xml?#2016-03-2007:19juhoteperiThe cljs sources are not included in the jar because src-cljs folder is not in source-paths#2016-03-2008:46juhoteperi@martinklepsch: Did you test SVG badges without link in github?#2016-03-2008:46juhoteperiLooks like unfortunately github will always wrap images in link#2016-03-2008:47martinklepsch@juhoteperi: even if you use <img>?#2016-03-2008:47juhoteperiYeah#2016-03-2008:50martinklepsch😕#2016-03-2008:50juhoteperiTesting with current badges here: https://github.com/cljsjs/packages/blob/master/airbrake/README.md#2016-03-2008:54juhoteperiTime to write update_readme_versions.sh for cljsjs I think!#2016-03-2017:38chrisoakman@juhoteperi: perfect! thank you so much#2016-03-2021:04danielcompton@juhoteperi: I don’t see the badge on that page?#2016-03-2021:05juhoteperiBecause I couldn't get them work like I wanted so I removed them#2016-03-2322:19eyelidlessnessmaybe i’m just lost, but i can’t find a place in my clojars profile to enter my public key.#2016-03-2322:21eyelidlessnesslike the field appears to no longer exist#2016-03-2323:11tcrawley@eyelidlessness: correct, the field no longer exists. we don't use PGP keys any longer, since we don't have a "promoted" repo#2016-03-2323:13eyelidlessnessthanks#2016-03-2406:57danielcomptonWould be interested to hear people’s thoughts on ^^#2016-03-2420:52gowderMight be worth looking at the EFF's thoughts on such matters, e.g. https://www.eff.org/pages/who-has-your-back-copyright-trademark-2014#2016-03-2421:16danielcomptonThe thing to remember about all of those companies is that they have a well funded legal department, Clojars doesn’t simple_smile#2016-03-2503:35gowderTruth. Intellectual property is kinda broken and there are no easy solutions...#2016-03-2503:36danielcomptonTBH I don’t find trademark law too offensive#2016-03-2503:36danielcomptonPatents and copyright yes, but trademark law is mostly sensible#2016-03-2503:59gowderIt's the least bad of the lot, to be sure. But that's not saying a whole lot. Much of the problem is from cases like this, where there's no way that two products are competing with one another, but someone overused a trademark for no real reason#2016-03-2504:00gowderLike really, is some dev utility for node going to compete in any way with some chat app for tweenies, or confuse any consumer ever? Nope.#2016-03-2504:02gowderAnd if people can get away with these overbroad claims because of intimidation, then there are no names left. If you search the registered trademark database for anything, no matter how common a word, you get a bizallion marks#2016-03-2504:19danielcomptonI could be wrong on the specifics here, but my understanding is that this only came up when Kik wanted to publish a package to NPM and found that there was already an NPM package called Kik. Trademarks are there to protect consumers and avoid confusion. Kik as an NPM module vs the chat service there is low risk of confusion, but if Kik are now publishing an NPM module then it becomes a little more understandable that there is confusion possible. Not saying I like it, but this is the world we live in simple_smile#2016-03-2514:25jsa-aerialThis sounds at root a problem with NPM not being able to provide a richer category / name-space to allow same names in separate spaces#2016-03-2514:28arrdemThat was my original reaction, but consider the case of someone making a stink for a group name. #2016-03-2514:30arrdemEx what if I pushed a jar to com.cognitect/foo. Would that be honored? How about com.factual/foo my former employer etc. #2016-03-2514:32gowderBut now imagine the natural extension of that Kik-entering-npm example. Suppose the person who owns the Cat Lady trademark decides, "hey, I'm going to expand from selling cat toys or whatever into making a node app that produces cat ascii art." And then they're shocked, shocked, to find that there's a node app called cat lady. ...#2016-03-2514:33jsa-aerialJust have some 'canned' and 'obvious' spaces and don't allow users to create their own categories. Things like 'apps' and 'libs', http://et.al. and some simple subcategories. Not perfect, but would likely solve most such cases#2016-03-2514:34jsa-aerialYou can break anything, but this sounds more like a case of a name clash preventing the other from being deployed at all - not so much the confusion stuff#2016-03-2514:37arrdemOkay so let's say that in an attempt to avoid this sort of thing clojars were to require an application for org.\ and com.\, and me.$USERNAME is all a user "just gets". Now some has to review group name applications, and still there are problems. What if someone else comes along and wants me.arrdem because I'm dead and they have a trademark. What if someone wrongly issues a group name? What if a group becomes defunct and someone else sues for it etc.#2016-03-2514:49jsa-aerialSure, most anything is possible, you are really just trying to reduce the probabilities.#2016-03-2515:01arrdemOne idea is to expose groups via two names. One is a uuid which we guarantee never to change or revoke, the other is a "human readable" groupname which may change in the future. On the tooling/client side users can then cache/override the upstream name to uuid mapping so if I wanted to use the old org.kik I just set a lein profile entry mapping that to the old uuid. #2016-03-2515:02arrdemThis requires reinventing less of Maven than other IPFS or Namecoin backed things I've seen thrown around recently. :/#2016-03-2515:04gowderThat's a really great idea @arrdem #2016-03-2517:41danielcomptonI highly recommend reading https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/metaschool/fisher/domain/tm.htm or some other 5 minute primer on trademark law, it was really helpful for me.#2016-03-2517:44danielcomptonIn the hypothetical cat lady example, Cat * is probably a descriptive mark, and so gets very little protection. If there was already a lib under cat-lady/cat-lady then that would probably be able to stay#2016-03-2517:46danielcomptonAnyhoo, I think this is very unlikely to happen to Clojars for a few reasons: 1. Clojure folk are pretty mature 2. The Clojure community is pretty tiny 3. Group names are common which help the namespacing problem 4. The main problem would be group name squatting, not artifact name squatting, which is easier to adjudicate 5. Most Clojure libs get named either very straightforward descriptive names, or fanciful creative names#2016-03-2518:16gowder@danielcompton: I agree on the substantive legal point about the example (and I actually learned my IP law from Terry Fisher, albeit almost 20 years ago), but the issue isn't the substantive legal question, the issue is how much power holders of registered trademarks have to intimidate people without money to litigate to give way beyond the scope of their substantive legal rights... That was really the issue with the Kik thing, as I interpret it. (But anyway, this is turning into a kinda off-topic discussion about how problematic trademark law is... Back to the main question, what about @arrdem 's dual-naming idea, that way if this ever does come up in clojars trademark disputes can be handled without breaking library access?)#2016-03-2518:26arrdemDisclaimer on the dual naming thing... I've been thinking for a while about how to do away with maven and manage dependencies via IPFS or bittorent or something else which provides different uniqueness properties and a fundamentally different distribution substrate. With some hacking I'm sure that you could write a leiningen plugin to support "hashdeps" or whatever you want to call these references, but the main idea in all that work is that names are not in fact a globally unique thing, rather they are largely contextual and so trying to come up with a naming permanence scheme which deals with all the complexities of IP law and assumes that whatever packages I publish under me.arrdem/* will be available until the heat death of the universe under that uncontested name is... silly. To @danielcompton's point I would agree. I think that by dint simply of having group names and using them, we're already way ahead of the Node crowd here and so rather than inventing a whole new dependency resolution system such as I was sketching at a simple statement of policy from the Clojars folks would probably be best.#2016-04-0913:28tcrawley@danielcompton: FYI - I'm uploading the repo from the server to rackspace cloudfiles currently#2016-04-0913:28tcrawleyit's going to take a while :)#2016-04-0913:29tcrawleyI've also implemented the bare minimum to put new deploys up there as well (not yet in production)#2016-04-0913:29tcrawleythat will allow us to beta test http://repo.clojars.org for a bit#2016-04-0914:28bostonaholicparrot#2016-04-0917:07tcrawleyit's been running for ~12 hours, and has transferred 2.5G. So, 5.5 days to go!#2016-04-1002:29danielcomptonNice!#2016-04-1903:59danielcomptonClojars is down because of a Linode outage#2016-04-1918:32arrdemgood thing I literally didn't plan on doing work today.#2016-04-1918:39tcrawley@arrdem: that was last night. it's up now#2016-06-0120:47danmidwoodHey Clojars, the lein-release group/artifact name contains releases from two separate projects- https://clojars.org/lein-release/ I just "upgraded" to the latest version suggested by lein-ancient which switched it from the one I intended to use to the one I didn't. Is this sort of thing common? Is it permitted or just a relic from the past (both plugins are quite old)?#2016-06-0121:40danielcompton@danmidwood: can you give an example of a release from each project?#2016-06-0121:43danmidwood@danielcompton: I posted about the same in #C03S1KBA2 before I discovered this channel and we've since had some discussion in there#2016-06-0121:44danmidwoodBut, to answer. 1.0.9 is the latest of relaynetwork's lein-release and the latest one released. 1.1.3 is the latest of technomancy's lein-release and was released ~6 years ago#2016-06-0516:40stathissiderishello, I can't find where I can paste my PGP key on clojars anymore#2016-06-0516:40stathissiderisused to be under "profile" right?#2016-06-0517:40malcolmsparksHello @stathissideris #2016-06-0517:40stathissiderishaha hello 🙂#2016-06-0518:11tcrawley@stathissideris: we no longer have a "promoted" repo, so no longer need PGP keys#2016-06-0518:12tcrawleywe just used them to validate the signature for promotion to the promoted repo#2016-06-0518:15tcrawleysee https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/415 for more details#2016-06-0518:29stathissideris@tcrawley: oh great, thanks, that makes sense#2016-06-0716:51vipacaHi, I am having trouble deploying a library to clojars. When I run lein deploy clojars I am asked to provide gpg key for signing, but I do not want to sign the package nor can find any information saying I must sign the package. What am I doing wrong?#2016-06-0717:44tcrawley@vipaca: by default, lein tries to sign releases. You can disable that by setting :sign-releases false in project.clj. Give me a sec and I'll give an example#2016-06-0717:46tcrawley
:deploy-repositories [["clojars" {:url ""
                                                     :sign-releases false}]]
#2016-06-0717:46tcrawleytry that#2016-06-0718:09vipacaAwesome this worked!#2016-06-0718:10vipacaI did add it to my profile.clj instead though. 
{:user
      {:deploy-repositories [["clojars" {:url ""
                                     :sign-releases false}]]}}
#2016-06-0718:20tcrawleygood deal#2016-06-1303:46billrobertson42I'm getting 401 errors attempting to publish. I published something last night with the same procedure with a different project. trigger to validate the deploy, copy it from a tmp repo to the live repo (part of the atomic deploy feature), and, just recently, to copy the project to Rackspace cloudfiles in anticipation of serving the repo from a CDN#2016-07-1816:56tcrawleyit's possible that that is all taking too long#2016-07-1816:56tcrawleydepending on the default timeout in aether#2016-07-1816:57daveliepmann@cap10morgan: I one w/ some debugging output turned on?#2016-07-1816:58tcrawleyI suspect we may need to move uploading to cloudfiles to a queue that gets processed async#2016-07-1816:59tcrawley@cap10morgan: let me add some timing output to the server side, give me a few minutes#2016-07-1816:59cap10morganOK, sounds good#2016-07-1816:59tcrawleyhow big is the jar for the project you are deploying?#2016-07-1817:00cap10morgan22K#2016-07-1817:00daveliepmann26K#2016-07-1817:02tcrawleythose are pretty small, I was thinking it was large uploads to cloudfiles causing the issue#2016-07-1817:26tcrawley@cap10morgan: @daveliepmann: I added some profiling to the validation and upload-to-cloudfiles code, and deployed a small test app#2016-07-1817:26tcrawleyIt didn't fail, but did take almost 8 seconds to validate + upload#2016-07-1817:26tcrawley950ms just to upload the 12k jar#2016-07-1817:26tcrawleyto cloudfiles#2016-07-1817:27tcrawleyso, if the timeout is 10s, we could very easily hit it#2016-07-1817:31tcrawleyyeah, it looks like 10s may be the default - I just recreated the issue by increasing the jar size to 23k#2016-07-1817:31tcrawleythe validate+upload took 9800ms, and it's safe to assume we're spending another 200ms outside of that process to get us over 10s#2016-07-1817:32tcrawleyI'm going to disable the cloudfiles upload for now, since we're not yet using the artifacts uploaded there#2016-07-1817:54tcrawley@cap10morgan: @daveliepmann: the cloudfiles uploads are now disabled in production. I just deployed my testapp, and the deploy time went from ~10s to 200ms. Please let me know if you continue to see the problem#2016-07-1817:55cap10morgan@tcrawley: cool, will do. thanks!#2016-07-2522:41danielcomptonClojars 46 out#2016-07-2522:45tcrawley@danielcompton: oops, sorry about the pedantic issue#2016-07-2522:47danielcomptonnp#2016-08-0508:55danielcomptonClojars maintenance starting soon#2016-08-0508:55danielcomptonhttp://status.clojars.org/incidents/36s65xgss7x0#2016-08-0509:12danielcomptonThat was suspiciously easy#2016-08-0510:25danielcomptonhttp://status.clojars.org/incidents/hdzvkpgdmwk9#2016-08-1402:09danielcompton@tcrawley: thanks for looking at this! Sorry about breaking the log parsing 😞#2016-08-1403:03tcrawley@danielcompton: No problem!#2016-08-1403:04tcrawleyWhile trying to figure it out, I set emails to the clojars user to go to /cdn-cgi/l/email-protection instead of /dev/null, that's why we now get cron output#2016-08-1404:04danielcomptonwas wondering why we started to get those 🙂#2016-08-1518:19pupenoHello.#2016-08-1518:19pupenoWhat’s the process to change the namespace of a jar?#2016-08-1519:11tcrawleypupeno: you push a new version with the new namespace, of you have rights to do so#2016-08-1519:11tcrawley@pupeno: ^ (in case the lack of an @ prevents notification)#2016-08-2008:53dialelohi, would it make sense for Clojars to support Cross-origin requests to its API?#2016-08-2008:54dialeloi'm building a site with our open source projects and want to display stats from Clojars#2016-08-2008:54dialeloideally without having to read Clojars data from a server#2016-08-2008:57dialeloi'm happy to open a PR if you think it could be useful#2016-08-2012:48tcrawley@dialelo: I think we should already have that according to https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/242 and https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/commit/b3572435e06bbd70336bcee8f209e8ae6c4f84b1 Is it not working for you?#2016-08-2108:34dialeloyou're right @tcrawley, i can make cross-origin requests just fine; sorry for the noise#2016-08-2111:43tcrawley@dialelo: no problem!#2016-09-0414:20firstclassfuncdoes anyone know if http://clojars.org is down?#2016-09-0421:06danielcompton@firstclassfunc http://status.clojars.org/incidents/lqt4r3lx4h6n#2016-09-0822:22gowderOh man, another attack on linode? This seems to be happening like crazy...#2016-09-1122:26michaseems to me that the fundamental problem is that our customers trust us with their data, and we implicitly trust the dependencies we use not to do anything bad#2016-09-1122:27michamaybe something like IPFS really is all we need#2016-09-1122:28michaand not even sign jars at all#2016-09-1122:39danielcomptonThere’s a few trust issues I think: 1. How do we verify that JARs we download from an untrusted source like Clojars haven’t been tampered with? 2. How do we verify that dependencies don’t do anything bad? 2. Seems to come down to auditing JAR updates before updating deps, I’m not sure how else you can verify that a dependency isn’t doing anything bad. 1. seems a little more tractable, by defining a mechanism for trusting a developer and therefore trusting their releases#2016-09-1122:54michayou could go the other way i suppose#2016-09-1122:55michaand just care about whether you have used those jars before in the past#2016-09-1122:55michaand you don't do any verification of gpg signatures or anything#2016-09-1122:56michamaybe IPFS provides such a mechanism#2016-09-1123:41danielcomptonsomething like https://github.com/WhisperSystems/gradle-witness ?#2016-09-1203:46onetom@micha im also thinking about these trust questions for many years. i've even participated in the http://cacert.org movement and got an assurer status > You have made 28 assurances which ranks you as the #1791 top assurer. > Total Points Issued: 901#2016-09-1203:48onetomi think the main problem is that trust is not a binary quantity and im not sure what the measure of trust should be. i understand proof of work is one proxy for this, but it's rather complicated infrastructure to setup, maintain, etc.#2016-09-1203:52onetomi have a gut feeling that mirroring how we gauge trust in real-world context every day would be a good enough solution. that could be done by 1. visualizing a trust network 2. calculate a trust score 3. allow hinting the calculation based on our preferences (eg. i dont really trust microsoft or verisign, but i trust micha) 4. visualizing/monitoring changes in the web of trust over time#2016-09-1203:52onetomit all hinges on what do we consider the electronic representation of identity of course#2016-09-1203:53onetomthis was quite well summarized in this famous keynote https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RrpajcAgR1E#2016-09-1203:54onetomso to me it's clear that identity can be a set of interconnected identity representations, which all add to the overall trust level#2016-09-1203:55onetompgp signatures can prove that an avatar and an email address are indeed represent a real individual#2016-09-1203:57onetomimean i can just choose to accept it as a proof and for example i would sign your gpg key based on the fact i've seen you in youtube talks and we had skype video chats and conversations about specific commits which bear your github username.#2016-09-1203:58onetomto me having such proof shown from a couple of community members who also trust each other would make your software a lot more trustable than being signed by come centralized CA with questionable security practices and opaque internal processes...#2016-09-1204:01onetombut i think the main problem is the lack of good UX for all this in the 1st place as @danielcompton points it out on https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/560#2016-09-1204:04onetomiirc the debian ecosystem was quite successfully maintaining a gpg ecosystem for their packager#2016-09-1204:05onetomthe 2nd problem could be the lack of protocol for representing such claims that i just made about micha for example. but let me know if you know about any good ones.#2016-09-1204:06richiardiandreaAgree on this latter point, and specifically, PGP done right works with actual I'd checks and of course is only an identity check. Then there is the "how much I trust you as a dev" part, and this can be a custom metric (# of project downloads on Clojars maybe) . This point for me is the part noone has yet solved, but GitHub is pretty much the implicit CA here. Everything coupled with ipfs to avoid dependency tampering (distributed, signed, high available deps)#2016-09-1204:06onetomim still not sure though how to trust the public keys from the various keyservers though... 😕#2016-09-1204:07richiardiandreaKeys could reside on ipfs as well?#2016-09-1204:07richiardiandreaDo you mean in terms of trust or tampering?#2016-09-1204:07onetomjust trust#2016-09-1204:09richiardiandreaYeah trust as a "good dev" is a difficult concept to measure, but there can be ways imho, we have so much info on GitHub/BitBucket..of course nothing really as accurate as coding shoulder to shoulder..#2016-09-1204:09onetomlike if none of my trusted identities are transitively trusting an identity, how do i know it's not someone impersonating a specific email and natural-name combination?#2016-09-1204:11onetomwell, i think trust is difficult to measure on a unified scale, BUT that's why in point 2 & 3 i proposed having parametric algorithms which everyone / every organization can customize/tune for themselves#2016-09-1204:12onetomthey can combine extra rules, like github metrics into their /user or /org trust score formula and thats it#2016-09-1204:13onetomit helps to compare libraries against each other and also monitor over time the trust level of the various software components within the organization#2016-09-1204:13richiardiandreaYeah well, impersonation is very very complicated to ascertain in the digital world..and maybe a bit off here, at the end of the day we want to first of all be sure that the coder is trustful and she is not including strange stuff in the oss library I am using..#2016-09-1204:14richiardiandreaYeah I like the above#2016-09-1204:14onetomso we don't have to tackle the problem of globally understood and accepted trust score calculation...#2016-09-1204:15onetomyet it would be very useful and already better that what we have right now, which roughly equals to: 1. blind trust 2. trust central corporations because we have to pay them for witnessing information...#2016-09-1204:16richiardiandreaAgree, also successful peer reviews could increase the "trust score" #2016-09-1204:17onetomand what we havent talked about yet is digitally signed timestamps which should ideally accompany all signatures, so we can't cheat on time either...#2016-09-1204:18onetomit should be easy to setup a time stamping service just for being able to fully dissolve centralization, but a few years ago when i checked i havent found any easy solution to this either...#2016-09-1204:20richiardiandreaUhm yeah nothing comes to mind actually, the signed timestamp is implicit when you deploy an artifact right? It would be implicit in ipfs#2016-09-1204:24onetom@richiardiandrea which part of IPFS ensures trustable time stamping?#2016-09-1204:25onetom(i still don't know the whole IPFS in and out, that's why im asking)#2016-09-1204:27onetomjust to be clear im talking about https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_timestamping#Trusted_.28digital.29_timestamping specifically#2016-09-1204:30onetomso i imagine an interface which shows all of the players in a trust network, assigns default scores to them, but presents a list where you can override these. for example if something is timestamped with a privately operated timestamp server, i could say i don't trust it, but if i happen to trust the operator of it, then it's default wouldn't be "dont trust"#2016-09-1204:34richiardiandreaReading#2016-09-1204:36richiardiandreaOh ok that's a different UX, I was just thinking of an implicit stamped timestamp as part of the (immutable) metadata sent over with an artifact..I see you are talking about something else ;)#2016-09-1218:08miikkaRegarding the security discussion: here's a specification for securing package indexes like Clojars. https://theupdateframework.github.io#2016-09-1218:08miikkaAnd here's a summary about it in the context of Python: https://lwn.net/Articles/629426/#2016-09-1218:09miikkaOther languages have investigated it as well - at least Ruby, Haskell and Rust - but I can't tell if any of the implementations is complete#2016-09-1218:12miikkaI'm not sure how easy it would be to adapt to Maven repos, but it's worth taking a look.#2016-09-1219:08flyboarderA few thoughts RE: Security: 1. The repo is your only real source of truth, packages and even compilers can be hacked. 2. That means that the only way to really validate code is to a. trust a developer (and the access control on the repo) and b. content address the code to make sure your getting what the trusted dev was intending. 3. Ideally at the repo level trust is established socially via real world interactions which could also be related to online activity like github data (this is kinda what we already do, for better or worse) 4. In order to validate the packages content, you cannot receive the verification data and the package from the same source, this is a basic single point of failure in any architecture. It’s not that I don’t trust clojars, it’s that it makes them a single point of failure and also means they are the ones telling me what my trusted developers packages are. 5. Whats needed is a way to verify from the developer what the data should be (or from the repo directly) or any other distributed trust, and then verify that against the packages, in transit security is “good enough” already if you are using certificates 6. none of this takes into account the versioning or human readable layer to all this, versions would basically be sugar on top of all the verification, since it’s still needed in a package manager.#2016-09-1219:31xcthulhu> Whats needed is a way to verify from the developer what the data should be (or from the repo directly) or any other distributed trust, and then verify that against the packages, in transit security is “good enough” already if you are using certificates Okay, as I have pointed out elsewhere, IPFS literally dogfoods itself in its source code to get upstream dependencies and avoids trusting certs - https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/blob/0e2b4eb4eb68fab5497d0e8f8472d025b5c1d431/core/corenet/net.go#L7#2016-09-1219:33flyboarderI agree IPFS is probably the way to go#2016-09-1219:35xcthulhuNow, registries can also be hacked, but you could write an append-only registry on a blockchain.#2016-09-1219:35flyboardercouldnt you just use ipfs as the registry#2016-09-1219:35xcthulhuYeah, they have a nameservice thingy#2016-09-1219:35xcthulhuI'm not sure how to make it append-only#2016-09-1219:36flyboarderi think that would be more for the ipfs app to handle#2016-09-1219:38xcthulhuIPFS isn't a consensus layer, it's a content addressable storage and delivery mechanism with a distributed hash table.#2016-09-1219:38flyboarder@xcthulhu there is this also https://github.com/ipfs/notes/issues/148#2016-09-1219:38xcthulhuYeah, it's a TODO#2016-09-1219:38xcthulhuBut as far as I know it's not part of the white paper or anything#2016-09-1219:40flyboarderYeah seems very concept#2016-09-1219:41xcthulhuYou can already make a registry using a blockchain#2016-09-1219:41xcthulhuIt's just a lot of work to get integration.#2016-09-1220:12tcrawleywow, lots of activity around securing clojars while I was on vacation. That's great that folks are interested!#2016-09-1220:12tcrawleythere's lots to reply to here, but a few initial thoughts:#2016-09-1220:14tcrawleyclojars is currently a standard maven repo (from a read point of view). Moving away from that to some custom format or distribution protocol would mean providing plugins for any build tool that would access it (currently maven, boot, lein, gradle, plus scripts that wget/curl deps directly)#2016-09-1220:16tcrawleyIIUC, IPFS would provide immutability and distribution, but couldn't guarantee that version X+1 was published by the same party as version X. All we can know is the version X that we pulled yesterday is the same as the version X we pulled today (which can only be done currently by keeping the hash of X local, so when you pull it again you can verify you are getting the same thing)#2016-09-1220:16tcrawleyplease correct me if I'm wrong, my understanding of IPFS is surface#2016-09-1220:17tcrawleywe're working towards putting the repo behind a CDN, and have been working towards that for 9 months. That's a simple change when compared to moving to IPFS, so I can only imagine that transition would take years to implement#2016-09-1220:18tcrawleywe actually don't want true immutability, given that there are legitimate reasons to remove artifacts (which are all handled by the admins, never by users directly)#2016-09-1220:20tcrawleywe use gpg because maven does, but gpg is nothing without a WoT and a way to verify that (which has been touched on several times)#2016-09-1220:21tcrawleyI think the best approach here is to enumerate the real problems here as gh issues (https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues), without discussing technologies initially - we need a clear statement of what the issues actually are#2016-09-1220:23tcrawleyand, tbh, if users have to understand IPFS and/or blockchains to build, then we're here: http://howfuckedismydatabase.com/nosql/fault-tolerance.png#2016-09-1220:46micha@tcrawley are there really cases where you must delete an artifact after it's been published? like i see reasons why it's desired, but i'm not aware of any real need?#2016-09-1220:47michalike if i accidentally push an artifact, like boot with version 9999.0.0 by accident#2016-09-1220:47michait's not awesome, but it's also just a number#2016-09-1220:48michai could push the next artifact with version 10000.0.0#2016-09-1220:50tcrawley@micha: the "must" case is when a user accidentally pushes private code or credentials in a jar#2016-09-1220:51tcrawleythose generally don't even show up as gh issues, they mail <mailto:/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection|/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection>#2016-09-1220:52tcrawleyI don't delete in the case of "version X is broken and I want to replace it"#2016-09-1221:25michaah, private code is an interesting case#2016-09-1221:26michacredentials i don't really think is a problem that needs deletion because you must assume they've been compromised anyway. if you don't you're negligent imo#2016-09-1221:27michabut private code though, that's interesting, or i guess code you aren't authorized to upload to clojars in the first place#2016-09-1221:28tcrawleyyeah, good point re: credentials. I don't think we've ever had that case, it's always been code you don't have rights to release#2016-09-1221:29michai wonder if a cooling-off period would be sufficient?#2016-09-1221:29michalike a level 1 cache that isn't in the immutable store for some amount of time#2016-09-1221:29michaonly visible to the user who uploaded the artifact or something?#2016-09-1221:30michaperhaps like the "promote" button we currently have#2016-09-1221:31michai guess the legal situation maybe makes immutability a no-go fundamentally#2016-09-1221:33juhoteperi(There has not been promote button in nearly a year)#2016-09-1221:33michaoh wow#2016-09-1221:33michaso it wasn't immutable#2016-09-1221:34tcrawleywhat wasn't immutable?#2016-09-1221:34michasorry bad joke#2016-09-1221:34tcrawleyah :)#2016-09-1221:34tcrawleythe promote button was part of the trusted repo feature that was never finished and never used#2016-09-1221:35tcrawleyit just led to confusion#2016-09-1221:35tcrawleythat's how http://oss.sonatype.org works - you deploy to a staging repo, then manually release once you are happy with it#2016-09-1221:36tcrawleybut maven users hated that step so much that sonatype released a plugin that auto-releases for you#2016-09-1221:36michaclojars can still be directed by a court to remove something or sued if you can't do it#2016-09-1221:36tcrawleydoing away with some of the value of the staging repo#2016-09-1221:36michaso it seems that immutablility is a pipe dream for a real repo#2016-09-1221:36tcrawleyyes, and at this point, that would mean I would get sued directly. which is fun to think about#2016-09-1221:37tcrawleyTHANKS FOR BRINGING IT UP#2016-09-1221:37michaoh man sorry#2016-09-1221:37tcrawley:)#2016-09-1221:37michai'll send you a file in a cake#2016-09-1221:38tcrawleya jar file?#2016-09-1221:38michahahahaha#2016-09-1221:38michamost disappointing mail call ever#2016-09-1221:39michajars got me in here, jars will get me out#2016-09-1221:39tcrawleyheh#2016-09-1221:40michathings like poms can be stored immutably though#2016-09-1221:40michaor metadata#2016-09-1221:40michait's only the actual artifacts that are a liability, maybe#2016-09-1221:42tcrawleywhat does that buy us?#2016-09-1221:43michathe ability to verify that an artifact at some URL has the right contents#2016-09-1221:44michaand also the history of contents that have ever been at that URL#2016-09-1221:44michaso you'd at least be able to know if an artifact has been modified#2016-09-1221:47michalike if there was a repo-wide metadata file in git, sort of#2016-09-1221:47michawhen something is changed or added you make a commit#2016-09-1221:47michatools could then refuse to use artifacts that aren't in the metadata file or have the wrong hash or whatever#2016-09-1221:48michayou could still delete the artifact from storage if you need to#2016-09-1221:49michawithout deleting the metadata from git, you just make a revert instead, so you preserve the ability to audit#2016-09-1222:26flyboarder@danielcompton nice summary#2016-09-1222:26danielcomptonthanks#2016-09-1816:59smaantHi guys. I’m looking into the feed.clj.gz file format, am I right that 1) versions should be sorted by time of release 2) scm.tag is the commit of the latest release? If the both are ‘yes’, then there’s probably a bug there, for instance: 
{:group-id "org.clojars.smallrivers", :artifact-id "aleph", :description "a framework for asynchronous communication", :scm {:connection "scm:git:", :developer-connection "scm:git:", :tag "a361d01502e6711a845a184b783685d264a0bd45", :url ""}, :versions ["0.2.1-SNAPSHOT" "0.2.1-rc5" "0.2.1-rc4" "0.2.1-alpha2-SNAPSHOT”]}
however on clojars versions are sorted as: 0.2.1-rc5 0.2.1-rc4 0.2.1-SNAPSHOT 0.2.1-alpha2-SNAPSHOT#2016-09-1817:01smaantalso :tag in the feed points to the 0.2.1-SNAPSHOT which is probably not the latest one (but the first in the :versions)#2016-09-1817:13tcrawley@smaant it doesn't look like we do any sorting on that data, but would welcome a PR to fix the sorting and to show the latest scm. The feed is generated here: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/tree/master/src/clojars/tools/generate_feeds.clj#L13#2016-09-1817:14smaantYeah, i’m looking at it right now too#2016-09-1817:16smaantWill do a PR, yes. Would you mind if I also extend format a little bit - I want to have tags for all versions? Will make it backward compatible with current one.#2016-09-1817:24tcrawleyYep, that's fine as long as it stays backward compatible. Would you mind filing an issue for it as well for release tracking purposes?#2016-09-1817:26smaantOne for bug and another for extension?#2016-09-1817:30tcrawleyyes, 2 issues probably makes sense#2016-09-1818:21smaant@tcrawley i would probably need some input here https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/563#2016-09-1904:38danielcompton
FAIL in (repair-metadata-corrects-versions) (repair_metadata.clj:53)
creates the correct metadata
expected: (= ["0.1.0" "0.2.0" "0.4.0" "0.5.0-SNAPSHOT"] (.getVersions versioning))
  actual: (not (= ["0.1.0" "0.2.0" "0.4.0" "0.5.0-SNAPSHOT"] ["0.2.0" "0.5.0-SNAPSHOT" "0.1.0" "0.4.0"]))
#2016-09-1904:38danielcomptonthis is failing on a new ubuntu server, but not on my Mac, or in CI#2016-09-1904:38danielcomptonI’m a bit puzzled#2016-09-1911:31tcrawley.getVersions should return the versions in the order they appear in maven-metadata.xml (I think). We add them in dir last modified order (https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/tree/master/src/clojars/tools/repair_metadata.clj#L66)#2016-09-1911:32tcrawleymaybe the version of java or the underlying syscalls used by FileUtils/copyDirectory copy in a different order on the new machine: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/tree/master/test/clojars/test/unit/tools/repair_metadata.clj#L17#2016-09-1920:29danielcomptonI may be doing something silly, but leiningen seems to hang when I put a clojars repo replacement in the :user profile#2016-09-1920:29danielcomptonit downloads from Central fine though#2016-09-1920:30danielcomptonoh wait#2016-09-1920:30danielcomptonit was doing a lein-npm install#2016-09-2023:20danielcomptonhttps://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clojure/yKir1dJO6cg#2016-09-2023:20danielcomptonTesting needed for new Clojars beta infrastructure. More details ^^#2016-09-2414:14tuhlmannHi there. What do the current maintainer and I have to do in order to make that work? :repositories [["clojars" {:url ""}]]
:plugin-repositories [["clojars" {:url ""}]]
#2016-10-1712:53tcrawleyin your :user profile#2016-10-1712:54tcrawleyyou'll get a warning from lein about having repos in the :user profile, but you can ignore that for now#2016-10-1712:56andrewboltachevI haven't had this file btw:#2016-10-1712:56andrewboltachev
{:user {
        :repositories [["clojars" {:url ""}]]
        :plugin-repositories [["clojars" {:url ""}]]

        }}

You are welcome to take a look at what you have to see what would need to change if you like: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-server-config#2016-10-1715:54mpenetone of the big missing piece might be auth on the artifacts. if I am not mistaken now they are served via nginx directly#2016-10-1715:56mpenetyup: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-server-config/blob/master/roles/clojars/templates/clojars.nginx.conf.j2#L104-L110#2016-10-1715:57mpenetthen maybe it makes sense to map auth on these to user/groups credentials (thinking out loud)#2016-10-1715:59mpenetalso another question would be do we want to allow auth per artifact or is it an on/off switch that applies to the whole instance#2016-10-1716:00mpenetserving the artifacts via nginx is a good thing, that's where all the pressure is and it's the perfect solution doing the heavy duty work, I don't know if it can be reconfigured "dynamically" for the auth part#2016-10-1716:05mpenetmaybe with lua + redis (for instance). But yeah, I know, it's another dependency ...#2016-10-1716:08mpenetcool stuff: https://nginx.org/en/docs/http/ngx_http_auth_request_module.html#2016-10-1716:09mpenetanyway, I ll stop flooding for now and look into this a bit on my free time 😆#2016-10-1819:30nesif I try to deploy to clojars but I put the password incorrectly, the lib is not available to my projects unless I re deploy correctly. I suppose I need to pass some argument to setup-dev to point to repo?#2016-12-2117:17dottedmagHmm, I have supplied a config using JAVA_TOOL_OPTIONS=-Dclojars.config.file=dev-resources/config.clj, now it indexed something.#2016-12-2117:42dottedmagHeh, I made it work, but it's not user-friendly. E.g. all releases uploaded yesterday: https://clojars.org/search?q=at%3A%5B1482255662000+TO+1482342072000%5D#2016-12-2117:42dottedmagThe numbers are, obviously, Unix timestamps in milliseconds.#2016-12-2117:42dottedmagSyntax is straightforward Lucene.#2016-12-2118:36dottedmagSearch is a Lucene query, so to make it better one has to traverse Query returned by Lucene parser and adjust all kinds of queries using field at. Not hard, but cumbersome.#2016-12-2814:25tcrawley@dottedmag: thanks for the feedback. I've fixed up the local dev experience a bit: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/commit/5eb77a4fab0ee2ed0857bd3ea844c9f3e9a4f7aa#2016-12-2814:26tcrawley@dottedmag: for the search stuff, let us know if there is anything we can do to improve that. Thanks,#2017-01-0205:33danielcomptonPgp was removed a while ago from Clojars#2017-01-0205:33danielcomptonAs it didn't provide a meaningful security benefit#2017-01-0208:39danielcompton@athinggoingon there's only 2 things now to change on the profile screen, email and password#2017-01-0208:40danielcomptonso that's all there is to see#2017-01-0510:17juhoteperiAny idea what could cause Broken Pipe Exception when deploying to Clojars?#2017-01-0510:18juhoteperiE.g. https://circleci.com/gh/cljsjs/packages/1443#2017-01-0510:18juhoteperiInterestingly build 1436 succeeded and I haven't changed configuration after that#2017-01-0517:43tcrawley@juhoteperi: I don't see any errors in the http://clojars.org logs. I do see entries for the files that were successful, but nothing for the failed jars#2017-01-0517:44tcrawleycan you try against http://clojars.org/repo/ instead? http://repo.clojars.org 302's to http://clojars.org/repo/, but something may be causing that initial request to timeout for some reason#2017-01-0517:44tcrawleythough you would think that would affect all the files, not just the jars#2017-01-0517:44juhoteperiCould the cdn have size limit?#2017-01-0517:45juhoteperiThough the jars shouldn't be particularly large, 700KB or something#2017-01-0517:46tcrawleyhmm, I wonder. maybe there is a limitation there - the full file may be uploaded before the 302 is issued, which would mean 1) the cdn would need to accept the full size, and 2) aether will upload each file twice#2017-01-0517:46tcrawley302'ing may be a bad idea :(#2017-01-0517:47juhoteperihmm not sure how http works in this case#2017-01-0517:47juhoteperitrying direct url now#2017-01-0517:50juhoteperidirect url works#2017-01-0517:53juhoteperiCould Fastly be configured to just proxy PUT requests to real server?#2017-01-0517:59juhoteperiBased on CDN announcement, there is currently one origin set up for Fastly, Rackspace Cloud Files#2017-01-0518:00juhoteperiI think it would be possible to set up http://clojars.org/repo/ as another origin, and add request rule to direct PUT requests to that and not cache them#2017-01-0518:00juhoteperiThen there wouldn't be need for redirect#2017-01-0518:29tcrawley@juhoteperi: I don't understand, what do you mean by "another origin"? http://clojars.org/repo/ is the canonical deploy url, and the legacy read url. The redir solution that is currently in place is just to support boot, since it doesn't have a concept of two different urls for the same repo#2017-01-0518:30tcrawleythe CDN currently doesn't cache anything uploaded to it, it just tries to redirect to http://clojars.org/repo/#2017-01-0518:30tcrawleythe http://clojars.org server then uploads to Cloud Files once the upload is complete, then it can be served by the CDN#2017-01-0518:30tcrawleyI'll see if I can proxy from the CDN instead of redirect though#2017-01-0518:31tcrawleythat may not be an option#2017-01-0518:34juhoteperiIs it normal for maven repos have different read and deploy urls?#2017-01-0518:35juhoteperiWe talked about adding support for separate deploy urls on #boot but weren't sure how common this is#2017-01-0518:36tcrawleywell, for nexus, you do have different urls, because deploys go to a staging repo first, so you are deploying to that#2017-01-0518:37tcrawleyI'm not sure about archiva, but nexus is the primary repo implementation#2017-01-0520:54danielcompton@tcrawley the proxying should be fine, I'm pretty sure Fastly will stream it through without holding onto it all#2017-01-0520:55tcrawleycool, we just need to figure that out#2017-01-0522:45juhoteperi"origin" is the source for CDN, if I understand correctly, currently CDN loads files from Cloud Files#2017-01-0522:45juhoteperiBut CDN probably can have several origins#2017-01-0523:21danielcompton@juhoteperi yep, that’s what we want to do I think. To clarify, this is probably what we want to happen: * GET/HEAD requests to Fastly are cacheable and go to Rackspace cloudfiles * POST requests to Fastly are passed straight through to the http://clojars.org webapp#2017-01-0523:57juhoteperiYeah#2017-01-0618:21dottedmagIs there statistics on number of downloads of jars? Probably there is some on CDN, but is there anything publicly available?#2017-01-0619:47mpenetThere is on a release page in clojars#2017-01-0619:48mpenetNot sure how accurate it is tho#2017-01-0619:49tcrawley@dottedmag stats are available on the page for each project, and from the api: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data#2017-01-0619:50tcrawleyit should be fairly accurate for requests that hit the server or the CDN. It's not a real indication of usage, though, since we don't know about stats from any caching proxies (nexus, archiva, etc)#2017-01-0619:50dottedmagThank you.#2017-01-2019:45danielszhttps://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/615#2017-01-2804:12eslachanceI'm having a bit of trouble with deploying to clojars (windows install).                         ["snapshots" {:sign-releases false :url ""}]]

So if the maven-metadata.xml that specifies the latest snapshot was requested in the last 15 minutes, you'll get the old file#2017-02-2801:38richiardiandrea@tcrawley tnx did not know that#2017-02-2821:00richiardiandreahey folks, is there a place to share ideas for the clojars website?#2017-02-2821:01tcrawleysure! you can drop them here or file an issue at https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues#2017-02-2821:52danielcompton@richiardiandrea I opened https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/625 for you#2017-02-2821:53richiardiandrea@danielcompton oh cool, i just deployed and went for lunch in order to wait 15 mins 😀#2017-02-2821:53richiardiandreaUnfortunately I have to try with the deployed artifact because I resolve it at runtime#2017-02-2821:58tcrawley@richiardiandrea you could resolve against http://clojars.org/repo/, that isn't behind the CDN, and will be updated immediately#2017-02-2821:59richiardiandreaAh! I just want to add a test for it, so I know when I've fixed it/break it in the future#2017-05-0517:40tcrawleybasically, I need to figure out how to get aether/deploy to reuse a cookie store between calls#2017-05-0517:40tcrawleywe do multiple deploys in the same test, but it doesn't share the cookies#2017-05-0517:41tcrawleybut does under boot, apparently#2017-05-0517:42flyboarderthat makes sense since the worker pod is constructed only once when the task it built#2017-05-0517:44tcrawleyI agree, except two aether/deploy calls right after each other in the clojars tests don't share :(#2017-05-0518:22flyboarder@tcrawley I fixed it by monkey-patching the push task, now uses a new pod each time the task runs, fixed the issue!#2017-05-0518:22tcrawleyheh, "fixed".#2017-05-0518:23tcrawleygood deal. I remember there was a recent discussion about it, but I can't find the discussion, and don't remember what was it about.#2017-05-2307:56tcrawley@dottedmag artifacts don't have to be signed, but if some artifacts in a deploy are signed, they all have to be signed. By default, lein wants to sign, but you can disable that#2017-06-0307:30martinklepschHey 🙂 I was wondering what people think about displaying snapshot versions (e.g. 0.4.2-20170301.173959-4) on Clojars? Depending on SNAPSHOTs is generally a bad idea unless you control the release cycle and I feel like it’s not common knowledge that you can use SNAPSHOTs without the pain#2017-06-0314:12martinklepschDoes Clojars also only keep the most recent snapshot as outlined here: https://docs.oracle.com/middleware/1212/core/MAVEN/maven_version.htm#MAVEN401 ?#2017-06-0421:25danielcomptonNope#2017-06-0421:25danielcomptonSee https://clojars.org/repo/re-frame/re-frame/0.8.0-SNAPSHOT/ for an example#2017-06-0421:27danielcomptonThe reason we don't remove them is so that you can depend on the full snapshot version like you showed 🙂#2017-06-0421:27danielcomptonWould be happy for an issue (and a patch 😛 ) about showing snapshot version numbers somewhere#2017-06-0520:58alex-dixonAnyone able to help a noob deploy to clojars? 🙂#2017-06-0609:41martinklepsch@danielcompton sweet thanks for the input#2017-06-0609:43martinklepsch@alex-dixon you might consider #beginners as well as it’s more active. Also mention what guide you have followed so far and what broke 🙂#2017-06-0609:45martinklepsch@danielcompton thanks, great to hear Clojars is doing The Right Thing ™#2017-06-0610:31martinklepsch@danielcompton are these versions tracked in the database at all currently?#2017-06-0610:56martinklepschIf they’re not stored in the DB then maybe a link to the /repo page of a snapshot version is a reasonable solution?#2017-06-0613:38alex-dixon@martinklepsch Thank you. I received help in #clojure and was able to deploy 🙂 The solution I received and problems I encountered are being discussed here https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/643#2017-06-0623:54danielcomptonAh yes, we don’t keep the full version number for snapshots. I'l take a look tomorrow#2017-06-1607:29martinklepsch@tcrawley no worries & safe travels 🙂#2017-07-2310:28timohi#2017-08-1820:54devthis there a straighforward way to deploy an uberjar to clojars?#2017-08-1820:54devthoh this might work https://github.com/BrightNorth/uberjar-deploy#2017-08-1820:55tcrawleyWhy are you wanting to deploy an uberjar?#2017-08-1820:58devthit's a lib that's meant to be used in Datomic#2017-08-1820:58devthDatomic doesn't resolve deps, so i'd either have to manually pull down all jars into Datomic's lib folder, or just deploy my lib as an uberjar so i can drop a single jar in#2017-08-1820:59devth(the only dep is timbre but timbe has its own deps)#2017-08-1821:00tcrawleyGotcha, that makes sense. I was just curious.#2017-08-1821:00tcrawleyThanks!#2017-08-1821:00devthnp#2017-09-1206:41kirangHi all, has Clojars removed support for signed releases?#2017-09-1207:08danielcompton@kirang yep https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/415#2017-09-1207:08danielcomptonyou can still sign releases, but Clojars doesn't have a separate repo for only signed JARs any more#2017-09-1207:41kirangThat helps. Thanks @danielcompton 🙂#2017-10-1021:15flyboarderHey everyone, looks like http://jarkeeper.com is down, does clojars have a badge for download count? https://shields.io only shows clojars version?#2017-10-1021:56tcrawley@flyboarder We don't have a badge for the download count, but do provide that info via the api: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data#2017-10-1022:37flyboarder@tcrawley so its possible :thinking_face:#2017-10-1618:46flyboarder@tcrawley is there a way to get the download stats as json?#2017-10-1618:48tcrawleyWe don't currently provide that, but could discuss it. Would you mind filing an issue at https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues for it?#2017-10-1618:53flyboarderdone!#2017-10-1919:27hlshipI know its a bit of a popularity contest, but I'm curious about top downloaded libraries.#2017-10-1920:11tcrawley@hlship We don't have anything that exposes top downloads, but all the data is at https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data#download-stats and should be pretty easy to analyze#2017-10-2213:52JonNeed help to setup Clojars on my new Macbook#2017-10-2213:52Jonany guide?#2017-10-2213:53Jonmostly on GPG part. I found some existing guide outdated.#2017-10-2214:48gonewest818@jiyinyiyong It seems to me (I can’t be sure, because I wasn’t using clojure back then) the clojars developers implemented gpg and ssh key verification, but due to whatever problems and confusion it created they backed that functionality out.#2017-10-2214:48gonewest818So where old documentation says stuff like “create a clojars account, and then go into your clojars profile and upload a ssh and a gpg public key” those screens are no longer in the clojars UI.#2017-10-2214:51gonewest818In the wiki documentation it now says, simply that it will check “if any signature is uploaded, then every artifact has a signature” but what that is NOT saying is “we confirm the signature belongs to the clojars account that is attempting to do the publishing” https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/pushing#validations#2017-10-2214:59gonewest818If you do a lein deps :verify in an existing project, you’ll probably see a mixture of :signed and :unsigned jars in your projects. If you read the verbose gpg output that gets printed to your shell you’ll also probably see statements like 
gpg: WARNING: This key has been revoked by its owner!
gpg:          This could mean that the signature is forged.
and 
gpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature!
gpg:          There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner.
and 
gpg: Note: This key has expired!
#2017-10-2215:05gonewest818And clojars developers seem very aware of these issues and (I think correctly) diagnosed the root problem: “...not many people promoted their artifacts, and there were minimal security benefits from signing the JARs, as people didn’t have a web of trust to validate that the GPG signature actually chained to people they trusted.” See for example https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clojure/-AIn1QlWyFs#2017-10-2215:14Jonslowly reading the words.... does it mean people barely sign their packages?#2017-10-2215:16gonewest818So the bottom line is, you can take the steps to generate a gpg keypair, sign and publish your public key to a keyserver, and make the necessary changes in profiles.clj to make sure artifacts are signed with the private key. You don’t need to submit your public key to clojars because clojars doesn’t verify signatures anymore. While leiningen can verify signatures, if you lift up that rock you may be disturbed by what you find underneath.#2017-10-2215:17Jonsigned but not used(only for verifying)?#2017-10-2215:18JonI'm still struggling to make uploading my package work..#2017-10-2215:28gonewest818Not sure I would say “people barely sign their jars” because I really don’t know what the statistics are. I suppose one could crawl the clojars repo and count the signed ones and find out. In my view the bigger issue is that even when people sign jars, the signatures aren’t meaningful unless the community makes the investment in building the necessary web of trust around the keys. The web of trust is necessary because it establishes the relationship between the keys and their owners. It’s not enough to have a signature on the file, you also need to know the signature is associated to the right person (the legitimate author of that library) and that you can trust that person.#2017-10-2215:32Jongood point though.#2017-10-2215:33JonI think I'm still on the beginner problems, rather than design choices.#2017-10-2215:33gonewest818What specifically isn’t working for you?#2017-10-2215:33Jonthe guides showed me GPG stuffs and I thought it was necessary.#2017-10-2215:34Jonwell, I think configuring GPG is too much complexity and want to send unsigned packages to Clojars.#2017-10-2215:34Jonkeep running into errors...#2017-10-2215:36Jonguides in Lein or Boot just assume the developers are experienced ones... but I actually come from JavaScript and think it in the way of npm. Never really understood we have so many steps to do to release.. packages.#2017-10-2215:39JonThanks. Since I confirmed that there are some people sending artifacts without signing... I can disable it in Boot now...#2017-10-2220:14danielcomptonI think you've mostly got it all correct there. Just to recap, there used to be two repositories, the 'free for all' where anyone could deploy to, and a 'releases' repository which was stricter. You had to deploy to the free-for-all repo and could then promote it to the releases repo if it passed certain requirements including GPG signing. This was very confusing for people, I don't think a lot of people used it, and as you've identified, without a WOT the signatures don't mean a lot. Anyone who had access to a users account (username/password) could also replace the GPG key in their profile. So we pulled out the releases repo and now there is just one repo. You can follow https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/560 if you're interested for a possible future#2017-10-2302:47Jonwas confused by the docs +1#2017-11-0116:12juhoteperiAny idea what happened with this package: http://repo.clojars.org/cljsjs/react-select/ https://clojars.org/cljsjs/react-select ? rc.10 is uploaded to the repo, but it is not shown on web Deploy threw this error: 
Could not transfer metadata cljsjs:react-select/maven-metadata.xml from/to clojars (): Access denied to: , ReasonPhrase: Forbidden - Serialized task failed.
#2017-11-0116:21tcrawley@juhoteperi Interesting, I'm not sure what that's about. The maven-metadata.xml shows 1.0.0-rc.10, do you happen to still have the full output of the deploy attempt?#2017-11-0116:22juhoteperihttps://circleci.com/gh/cljsjs/packages/2692 (not sure if you can see the output)#2017-11-0116:28tcrawleyI can see the output, thanks#2017-11-0116:28tcrawleyI don't see any errors in clojars' log, nor in sentry, so it's unclear why this failed#2017-11-0116:29tcrawleyThe "Serialized task failed" makes me think it had a problem writing to the db, possibly#2017-11-0116:30juhoteperiIs that message from Clojars backend?#2017-11-0116:30tcrawleyyes#2017-11-0116:31tcrawleyto support transactional deploys, we use the writing of the metadata file as a trigger to copy the tmp repo where we store your upload over to the real repo#2017-11-0116:31tcrawleyand do the validation/db updates at that point#2017-11-0116:32tcrawleyso this failure is likely unrelated to the metadata file itself#2017-11-0116:33tcrawleyIt looks like the release is there, but not listed in the db, so it doesn't show in the UI: https://clojars.org/repo/cljsjs/react-select/1.0.0-rc.10/#2017-11-0116:36tcrawleyWould you be willing to try releasing an rc11 to see if this was a temporary issue?#2017-11-0116:38juhoteperibuilding 1.0.0-rc.10-1 now (rc10 is the version of upstream package, don't want to touch that)#2017-11-0116:38tcrawleyah, understood#2017-11-0116:39juhoteperiStrange that the logs wouldn't contain this exception#2017-11-0116:40tcrawleyagreed :(#2017-11-0116:41juhoteperirepo routes seem to correctly catch-and-rethrow the exception, and repo routes are wrapped with repo/wrap-exceptions which should report them#2017-11-0116:43juhoteperiWorked now: https://clojars.org/cljsjs/react-select#2017-11-0116:48tcrawleyGlad it worked. Yeah, I agree - that should have gotten logged to stdout and to sentry, but it didn't go to either#2017-11-0116:50juhoteperiaha... I see it#2017-11-0116:50juhoteperiAny exception from repo routes is added :report? false metadata: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/blob/master/src/clojars/routes/repo.clj#L82 , which disables reporting https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/blob/master/src/clojars/errors.clj#L85#2017-11-0116:51juhoteperiMaybe that is to skip errors caused by e.g. trying to deploy same version again#2017-11-0116:51tcrawleygood catch, we shouldn't be doing that for all errors, the intent there was to not report validation errors to sentry, since those are user errors#2017-11-0116:52tcrawleywould you mind filing an issue for that?#2017-11-0116:52juhoteperiYeah I'll open one#2017-11-0116:53tcrawleythanks!#2017-11-1706:56Shantanu KumarHi, I’m looking at https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/About#how-do-i-delete-a-jar and I wonder if project rename could be a considered a valid reason for deleting a released artifact. In my case, I have released 0.1.0-alpha1 version that nobody else uses and I decided to rename the project before it’s too late.#2017-11-1707:00Shantanu Kumar^^^ /cc @danielcompton @tcrawley#2017-11-1716:36Alex Miller (Clojure team)hello kind clojarians.
