What version of java are you using?#2017-11-1716:37Alex Miller (Clojure team)java 1.7 in this terminal#2017-11-1716:38tcrawleylein 2.8.1 switched the clojars repo url to point to the CDN, which should support java 1.7, but may require a newer patch release#2017-11-1716:38tcrawleyyou can force it to use the on-server repo, which won't have that issue, one sec#2017-11-1716:39Alex Miller (Clojure team)interesting#2017-11-1716:40tcrawleyif you add :repositories [["clojars" {:url ""}]] to your :user profile in ~/.lein/profiles.clj, you'll hit the on-server repo (which is still valid and in-sync with the CDN)#2017-11-1716:40Alex Miller (Clojure team)on 1.7.0_25-b15 in particular#2017-11-1716:40tcrawleythough lein may warn about having repos in your user profile#2017-11-1716:40Alex Miller (Clojure team)I switched to java 1.8 and that did fix it#2017-11-1716:40Alex Miller (Clojure team)did not expect that to be a java version thing#2017-11-1716:41Alex Miller (Clojure team)thanks!!#2017-11-1716:41tcrawleyI believe the issue is SNA certificate support, which wasn't in earlier 1.7 builds#2017-11-1716:41tcrawleymy pleasure!#2017-11-1716:41Alex Miller (Clojure team)makes sense#2017-11-1716:41Alex Miller (Clojure team)hey, in the clojure cli stuff, what repo should I use as the default clojars repo?#2017-11-1716:42Alex Miller (Clojure team)I don’t have mirror support yet#2017-11-1716:42tcrawley@kumarshantanu I would just leave the old name there, deletion is problematic, and we'd like to avoid it if possible#2017-11-1716:43tcrawley@alexmiller I would use https://repo.clojars.org/ - that's the CDN, and we're trying to move all the tooling to it, since it is more reliable in theory#2017-11-1716:43Alex Miller (Clojure team)I’m using https://clojars.org/repo/ - is the cname preferred?#2017-11-1716:43tcrawleythat's the on-server repo, so the cname is preferred, yes#2017-11-1716:43Alex Miller (Clojure team)ok#2017-11-1716:44tcrawleythough that same SNA issue will occur for old javas#2017-11-1716:45Alex Miller (Clojure team)I’m ok with that as long as I know how to tell people to fix it :)#2017-11-1716:46tcrawleyright on#2017-11-1716:47Alex Miller (Clojure team)I somewhat intentionally run an old jvm as my default to avoid accidentally relying on anything too new when doing clojure dev :)#2017-11-1716:49tcrawleyuhm, yeah, that's, uhm, my excuse as well#2017-11-2014:00gfredericksdoes clojars have no mechanism for transferring ownership of a project?#2017-11-2014:01tcrawley@gfredericks ahoy hoy! Sure! You just add someone as a user, then make them an admin#2017-11-2014:02tcrawleythen have them log in and remove you if you want to be completely divorced#2017-11-2014:04gfredericksAh, okay thanks. I didn't see that in the ui#2017-11-2014:04tcrawleymy pleasure!#2017-11-2014:04gfredericksHi @tcrawley #2017-11-2014:08gfredericksoh is this only at the group level, not artifact?#2017-11-2014:10tcrawleycorrect, users are at the group level. You could probably tell rsync to only load pom files, not jars.#2018-03-1508:49xtreak29> If you want to use the actual repo from http://clojars.org, you can grab it via rsync.#2018-03-1508:49xtreak29> Note that this setup task isn't perfect - SNAPSHOTS won't have version-specific metadata (which won't matter for the operation of clojars, but may matter if you try to use the resulting repo as a real repo), and versions will be listed out of order on the project pages, but it should be good enough to test with. https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web#2018-03-1508:50xtreak29I am ok with non snapshot data but there is no information about the URL for rsync and so on.#2018-03-1508:50juhoteperiHmm? Wiki shows the rsync command#2018-03-1508:51xtreak29Yes, got it thanks : https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data#rsync-the-whole-repository#2018-03-1508:51xtreak29But as you said I need only the poms and not the jars#2018-03-1508:52juhoteperi--exclude '*.jar' might work, or --exclude '*' --include '*.pom'#2018-03-1508:54xtreak29Thanks a lot. I will try that.#2018-03-1508:58xtreak29I tried rsync -av --delete my-wonderful-copy-of-clojars --include="*/" --include="*.pom" --exclude="*" . It creates the folders. Around 42MB of empty folders but the pom files are printed on the screen and not downloaded. I cancelled in the middle. Am I missing something? I am trying to use the command against less data#2018-03-1508:59juhoteperimaybe change the include - exclude order, so that include is done after exclude#2018-03-1509:00xtreak29Is there a way to only do 10% of rsync or something?#2018-03-1509:02xtreak29Gets me an empty directory 
➜  ~ rsync -av --delete  my-wonderful-copy-of-clojars --exclude="*" --include="*/" --include="*.pom"
receiving incremental file list
./

sent 53 bytes  received 55 bytes  30.86 bytes/sec
total size is 0  speedup is 0.00
#2018-03-1509:52xtreak29rsync -av --delete my-wonderful-copy-of-clojars --include="*/" --include="*.pom" --exclude="*" works . It seems there are duplicate pom files that I need to clean up. Thanks a lot.#2018-03-1521:17danielcompton@xtreak29 there is also https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data which might have what you need, if not then open an issue and we might be able to add it#2018-03-1605:45xtreak29@danielcompton Thanks, the wiki was helpful. I used the above rsync command to download only the pom files of around 1GB of data. I am parsing them up to write to database. I could see multiple duplicate poms that result in duplicate data. Is there a reason for that? Does clojars have redundant copies for some reason? 
➜  my-wonderful-copy-of-clojars $ diff aleph/aleph/0.1.0-SNAPSHOT/aleph-0.1.0-20100502.112537-10.pom aleph/aleph/0.1.0-SNAPSHOT/aleph-0.1.0-20100502.112537-11.pom
No difference in the above as from the diff command.#2018-03-1605:50xtreak29If there is already a database present with this info it will save me a lot of time.#2018-03-1606:00danielcomptonThose are SNAPSHOT versions, they’re work in progress versions that people can publish. They probably have changed in source files but not necessarily in POM#2018-03-1606:00danielcomptonYou can probably ignore them TbH#2018-03-1606:10xtreak29Makes sense thanks. Is there a database already present with the info because some of the projects have some unicode symbols which break the XML parsing. E.g. file : my-wonderful-copy-of-clojars/speclj/speclj/2.1.3/speclj-2.1.3.pom content : <comments>Copyright \251 2011 Micah Martin All Rights Reserved.</comments> Exception : 
Unhandled java.lang.IllegalAccessException
   class clojure.lang.Reflector cannot access class
   com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.io.MalformedByteSequenceException (in module java.xml) be$
   java.xml does not export  to unnamed module @3629b018
#2018-03-1612:30tcrawley@xtreak29 be aware that just parsing the pom files will give you the direct dependencies, not the transitive dependencies the direct ones have. In order to get the full dependency tree, you’ll need to use a maven resolver to walk the tree#2018-03-1612:31tcrawleyone hacky (but somewhat straightforward) way to do that is with Maven: mvn -f /path/to/pom dependency:tree#2018-03-1612:32xtreak29Yes, that is a good catch. Also I could see some of the libraries using the dependencies as part of code and not as part of project.clj .#2018-03-1612:32tcrawleyright, those would be dependencies brought in transitively#2018-03-1612:32tcrawleywith dependency:tree, you’ll have to regex parse the output, but it’s regular at least#2018-03-1612:34xtreak29Looks like the above command downloads jars#2018-03-1612:34xtreak29
➜  ~ mvn -f my-wonderful-copy-of-clojars/speclj/speclj/2.6.1/speclj-2.6.1.pom dependency:tree
[INFO] Scanning for projects...
Downloading: 
Downloaded:  (6 KB at 2.9 KB/sec)
#2018-03-1612:34tcrawleyyes, it will resolve all the dependencies in order to process their pom files, unfortunately#2018-03-1612:34tcrawleyit will also download jars it needs to run dependency:tree#2018-03-1612:36xtreak29Got it. That will be a network heavy task for me. Since doing a full dependency detection of clojars in a tiny DigitalOcean droplet will kill it 🙂#2018-03-1612:37xtreak29Right now I have parsed the pom and inserted into MongoDB and using a query to see which libraries use dependencies that cannot run on Clojure 1.9 to file issues. 
> db.clojars.distinct("url", {dependencies: {$elemMatch : {artifactId: "core.async"}}, "version": {$lt: "0.3.442"}}, {url: 1, '_id': false})
[
	"",
	"",
	"",
]

#2018-03-1612:39xtreak29Problem is that there I parse every pom file and there are cases where the older maven file will tell me that there is an outdated dependency but it's fixed in the new one. Need to do something to get the latest pom in the directory to avoid false positives.#2018-03-1612:41xtreak29@tcrawley Do you know of any database that has all the info as a structured output, I am assuming that clojars uses a DB backend to construct the pages.#2018-03-1612:42tcrawleyClojars does store the direct dependencies in the db, but not the transitive ones#2018-03-1612:42xtreak29Is the db available for download somewhere in public ?#2018-03-1612:43xtreak29Assuming there is a dump of db or tables without any sensitive info I can use that instead of trying my own efforts.#2018-03-1612:44tcrawleyNo, there’s currently no way to get that db. We could possibly expose the dependencies via an api call, but that still wouldn’t give you the full tree#2018-03-1612:45tcrawleyand you’d be lacking any custom repos defined in the poms to resolve the transitive tree for those dependencies#2018-03-1612:46xtreak29Got it. With Boot, you don't need GPG at all to deploy to Clojars.#2018-05-2518:48seancorfieldWith Leiningen, GPG is only used to sign JARs (optional) and to encrypt/decrypt your Clojars credentials locally.#2018-05-2518:51seancorfieldSee https://github.com/boot-clj/boot/wiki/Repository-Credentials-and-Deploying for using Boot to deploy to Clojars @plins#2018-05-2518:52seancorfieldLeiningen has this comprehensive GPG guide https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/stable/doc/GPG.md#2018-05-2518:57seancorfieldLeiningen instructions https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/stable/doc/TUTORIAL.md#publishing-libraries (to enter username/password each time -- else you can store them per the GPG instructions)#2018-05-2520:46plinsThank sean, ive managed to upload it#2018-05-2906:28martinklepschAnother data/API question: is there some way to get recent releases?#2018-05-2906:35xtreak29@martinklepsch I think you can hit and take the first element of the array recent_versions which has the most recent release. I think it handles snapshots but I am not sure. Snapshot example : https://clojars.org/api/artifacts/ql Ref : https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data#endpoints#2018-05-2906:36martinklepsch@xtreak29 thanks, I was more looking for a “global feed” if that makes sense?#2018-05-2906:36martinklepschkind of what is displayed on the front page#2018-05-2906:43xtreak29Okay, I don't think it's exposed as an API. It does a SQL query against SQLite and the result is rendered in the template. SQL query : https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/blob/0a454d26440f33d49067f261d660de780c8f558a/resources/queries/sqlite-queryfile.sql#L159 Relevant function : https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/blob/f3c88a24ba29c5610827b0a8a759e3b1342a27fa/src/clojars/db.clj#L105 Relevant template : https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/blob/0a454d26440f33d49067f261d660de780c8f558a/src/clojars/web/dashboard.clj#L59#2018-05-2913:16martinklepsch@tcrawley are you aware of any way users could get a “feed” of releases on clojars? If not I would be happy to work on it.#2018-05-2913:24tcrawley@martinklepsch We don’t have anything formal, but it may be possible to simulate that now with a date-based query against the search api. That may allow you to get everything released since a certain date. Not the same thing, but would that work for your needs?#2018-05-2913:29martinklepschDo you have an example of how such query would look? I randomly tried https://clojars.org/search?q=incanter%20at:[2018-04-01%20TO%202018-04-10]&amp;format=json after looking at some code but not sure that’s what you mean? 😄#2018-05-2913:34tcrawleyYep, something like that. I’ve never used the date search. You may need to include the time info for dates to be processed properly, like: https://clojars.org/search?q=at:[2018-04-01T00:00:00Z%20TO%202018-04-10T00:00:00Z]&amp;format=json. Though That is paged in batches of 24, and I don’t recall how to get the next page. It’s clear that I never use search :)#2018-05-2913:50martinklepschOk, thanks for the pointer, will dig 🙂#2018-05-3016:53martinklepschsearching in json or xml didn’t respect the page param https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/pull/697#2018-05-3023:00hlshipI accidentally uploaded an artifact with the wrong version number. Is there a procedure to get rid of it? https://clojars.org/com.walmartlabs/lacinia/versions/0.28.0-rc-1 was wrong, the right version number is 0.27.0-rc-1 (which I just uploaded).#2018-05-3107:42martinklepsch@hlship I think the procedure is to open an issue on GitHub (see other ones with the Delete Request label) — @tcrawley or @danielcompton may then delete it eventually.#2018-05-3112:26tcrawley@hlship For cases like this (where the deploy is a forward version), we don’t delete it, since it’s possible for someone to notice it and depend on it before we’re able to remove it. We recommend you just skip 0.27.0. Feel free to blame us in the release notes :)#2018-06-0605:42GavinHello everyone, I am working on a simple Clojure 1.9 project. User will need to symlink the system CA certificates if necessary. I have fixed the builds in my project. It involved manually symlinking the system CA certs in the before_install stage. You can find this minimal Travis CI configurations as an example. Big thanks for your help! Guess I will ask lein if they like to change that over there 🙂 (see https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/1dc131128279ef50f21d4d643c4d5c2133c1370d/src/leiningen/pom.clj#L75)#2018-10-2521:04martinklepsch@hi895 that’s an interesting observation... there are some docs for cljdoc that also suggest using the https URL - do you think they should be changed? https://github.com/cljdoc/cljdoc/blob/master/doc/userguide/faq.md#2018-10-2605:15Jorinwill check it out 🙂#2018-10-2605:32JorinSeems like cljdoc is also affected by this. Guess that many projects are using lein for release. Since lein didn't put that info in the pom file for those repositories, it's hard to analyze it. I think the only reasonable place to fix this is in lein, not on the consumer side. There are many examples I came across: https://cljdoc.org/d/http-kit/http-kit/2.3.0 https://clojars.org/spootnik/signal If there is no url in the scm info in pom, can still use the main url tag in the pom file which probably points to a useful resource 🙂#2018-10-2521:07martinklepschFeel free to just do it or open an issue 🙌#2018-10-2619:48lilactown:thinking_face: so using ansi-term in Emacs, lein deploy clojars fails (typing in username and password) with a Return code is: 401, ReasonPhrase: Unauthorized#2018-10-2619:48lilactownrunning it in iTerm, succeeds#2018-10-2619:48lilactownanyone ran into this before?#2018-10-2619:49tcrawleyI suspect the username and password aren't making it to the lein process. #2019-06-0707:07miikkaI suppose it's the same thing as this one: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/700#2019-06-2011:12cddrHey Folks, Has anyone solved the problem of allowing project contributors the ability to publish a snapshot version of a project's jar (automatically in circleci/travis etc) in clojars without giving them the keys to the kingdom? We have a "deploy_snapshot" task in circleci that only works when members of our organization submit a PR. When those outside our org submit a PR, it fails at that step because circleci does not provide their build with the clojars credentials.#2019-06-2023:12danielcompton@cddr what doesn't work in the current situation? It sounds like what you've got is working?#2019-06-2023:48cddrSo when members of funding circle submit a PR to jackdaw, circleci publishes a snapshot build to clojars. This is helpful because we can deploy an app that uses the snapshot build into our test environments to make sure that the change is good. But when folks who are not members of the org publish a PR (e.g. https://github.com/FundingCircle/jackdaw/pull/149) circleci does not expose the clojars credentials to that build so the publish fails. I was wondering if it would be possible (or even desirable -- maybe it's a huge security risk) to allow PRs to publish snapshot builds initiated by outside users without giving them permission to publish proper releases. I think the workaround suggested by @andrea.crotti is that they could update the project.clj in their fork to publish under their own clojars group.#2019-06-2123:24danielcomptonThat’s really a CircleCI issue mostly I think? Or are you suggesting we make some other type of credentials that can only publish snapshots?#2019-06-2123:26danielcomptonI’d probably lightly discourage publishing untrusted snapshots. Also, what’s to stop the person bumping the version at the same time and publishing a release version?#2019-06-2123:28danielcomptonThat would require some kind of snapshot credential. And it would still fundamentally be leakable to third parties if it was exposed to untrusted PRs#2019-06-2123:29danielcomptonI’m not sure if the security problems are resolvable, but feel free to open an issue to discuss it more. But be sure to address how you’d avoid third parties getting the snapshot credentials#2019-06-2408:55cddrYeah I think you’re right. I’ll just document how people can publish their own snapshot.#2019-06-2707:36anirudhWe are facing problems with our Travis-CI. The build fails as it is not able to pull dependencies from maven

See https://groups.google.com/d/msg/clojure/ZXBOQD5Ubbc/D4ktv8aFCQAJ for details.#2019-12-2323:16sogaiuthanks for the link (and understanding)#2019-12-2323:23tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2019-12-2412:13dominicmDoes cloudfiles have an export functionality of some kind?#2019-12-2414:35tcrawley@dominicm no, just http. I'm not concerned about the cost of crawling the repo via http. We do publish a list of all jars in the repo, updated daily. So that could be used to pull down a copy of the repo, then later check for jars that aren't in the local copy and pull just those. Though that process would also have to have smarts around knowing that maven-metadata.xml files would need to be re-downloaded as well.#2019-12-2414:37dominicmYeah. If cost isn't a problem, then no worries. My use of rsync was to minimize bandwidth consumption.#2019-12-2717:57tcrawley#2020-01-2104:38Tamizhvendan SHi, I have published a library in Clojar (https://clojars.org/org.graphqlize/graphqlize) 12 hours ago but when I try to refer it via deps I am getting the following error 
Error building classpath. Could not find artifact org.graphqlize:graphlize:jar:0.1.0-alpha1 in central ()
How can I resolve it?#2020-01-2105:55sogaiumay be the following will be of some help. iiuc, the reason clojars gets consulted via clj is usually(?) because there is some deps.edn file that has a section like: 
:mvn/repos {
    "central" {:url ""}
    "clojars" {:url ""}
  }
on my machine that happens to be the file /usr/local/lib/clojure/deps.edn. i learned this by first examining the output of clj -Sdescribe and looking through the files listed under the :config-files key.#2020-01-2112:14Tamizhvendan SThanks @sogaiu. But it didn’t help. I even put :mvn/repos in deps file but still it didn’t work#2020-01-2112:21Tamizhvendan SOops. It was a typo. The quickest fix would be to release 1.5.5 - I won't have time to look in to how to fix 1.5.4 in the next 8 hours or so at least.#2020-01-2116:53darwinok, don’t worry about it, I will simply release a new one, only few people use this anyways#2020-01-2116:53darwinthanks#2020-01-2116:54tcrawleyMy pleasure! Sorry for the trouble.#2020-01-2408:52flowthingI have a CI build that executes build steps in parallel, and many of the download artifacts from Clojars. Every now and then, a build fails with something like Error building classpath. Could not transfer artifact ring:ring-defaults:jar:0.3.2 from/to clojars (): Connection reset or Error building classpath. Could not transfer artifact crypto-equality:crypto-equality:jar:1.0.0 from/to clojars (): /root/.m2/repository/crypto-equality/crypto-equality/1.0.0/crypto-equality-1.0.0.jar.part (No such file or directory). Is it possible that Clojars doesn't like my build downloading so many artifacts simultaneously? That is, does Clojars do some sort of throttling that might cause this? If so, that's fine and understandable — I'll just need to either forgo parallelism or try to figure out how to cache artifacts so that I don't need to redownload them on every build.#2020-01-2410:38tcrawleyHowdy @flowthing! There shouldn't be any throttling on the http://repo.clojars.org endpoint - that's handled by a fastly CDN. So I think that any connection resets may be random network errors. The latter error is local, not a network issue. I suspect that if those build steps are sharing an .m2/repository, you would get race conditions if they are trying to download the same artifacts at the same time. I would either: • try to resolve all dependencies before running parallel steps • give each step its own .m2/repository/ and cache that between builds#2020-01-2410:42flowthingMany thanks for looking into it! That makes total sense. I'll look into the options you suggested. I'm working with Google Cloud Build and I haven't been able to get .m2/repository caching to work, but I think the first option should be doable.#2020-01-2615:14borkdudeDependency question. When using a -SNAPSHOT version, I noticed you can replace the -SNAPSHOT with a date: clojure -Sdeps '{:deps {clj-kondo {:mvn/version "2020.01.14-20200126.145730-7"}}}' -m clj-kondo.main --lint - --config '{:output {:format :edn}}' <<< '(inc)' Are the dated snapshot versions persisted forever on clojars?#2020-01-2615:41tcrawleyYep! A timestamped snapshot is no different from a regularly versioned release. -SNAPSHOT is just a pointer to the latest timestamped release. That means you also cannot overwrite a timestamped release - they are immutable as well.#2020-01-2615:42borkdudeCool! How can I get timestamped releases from the clojars web page?#2020-01-2615:57tcrawleyThey aren't exposed in the UI - you have to look in the repo (http://repo.clojars.org/clj-kondo/clj-kondo/2020.01.14-SNAPSHOT/) or at the maven-metadata file for the snapshot (http://repo.clojars.org/clj-kondo/clj-kondo/2020.01.14-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xmll)#2020-01-2615:58borkdudeThanks!#2020-01-2615:58tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2020-01-3114:26plexusnot sure if this is already a known issue, but seems like these stats links have stopped working https://repo.clojars.org/stats#2020-01-3114:27plexusthe last two days are also missing from the index...#2020-01-3114:29tcrawley@plexus thanks for the report! I've been working on the stats code lately, and it looks like something is broken. I will try to get it sorted out over the weekend. I should be able to backfill the missing stats.#2020-01-3114:31plexusthank you!#2020-01-3114:31tcrawleyI suspect the broken links are a fastly misconfiguration.#2020-01-3114:39plexusI have backups, but only until early November 🙂 https://github.com/plexus/clojars-stats#2020-01-3114:39plexuswas hoping to update that repo to quickly pull out some download stats across time#2020-02-0115:35tcrawley@plexus https://repo.clojars.org/stats/ has correct links now, and is caught up to yesterday. There may still be a problem with the cronjob that generates the stats. If it doesn't run tonight I'll debug it tomorrow.#2020-02-0209:52plexusAwesome, thanks a lot!#2020-02-0214:45tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2020-02-0412:18vemvIf I have released an alpha release, e.g. my-project "2.0.1-alpha2", then will show that alpha as the most recent version, (and the one used in the Leiningen/Boot/`Clojure CLI/deps.edn` snippets) ...while that is technically true, it can lead people to believe they are supposed to consume this alpha, when in reality it has a narrower intended target audience. Wondering if this has been considered already?#2020-02-0412:25tcrawley@vemv It has! But there really hasn't been any discussion about it - https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/398 An issue is there really isn't a standard for what is or isn't a "stable" version other than a -SNAPSHOT isn't stable. We would either need to come up with that standard or allow the user a way to signal a version as non-stable - probably through the UI.#2020-02-0412:29vemvThank you! I'll try to contribute something to that thread, keeping your reply in mind.#2020-02-0412:29tcrawleyThanks!#2020-02-0818:59darwinany changes in content type returned by clojars recently? lein-ancient started failing on me with bunch of messages like: (warn) [clojars] - Δ 430ms - failure when checking cljs-http/cljs-http: java.lang.Exception: response content-type is not XML (#{"text/xml" "application/xml"}): application/octet-stream#2020-02-0821:17tcrawleyAh, I am working on moving the repo from cloudfiles to s3, and I switched to serving from s3 earlier today. It looks like that is breaking the content-types. I'll revert that change for now and work on getting that fixed.#2020-02-0821:18tcrawleyDone, though it may take a while for the changes to take affect.#2020-02-0819:21darwinbtw. this fixed it for me, but would be nice to still get confirmation from your side that content-type changed… https://github.com/xsc/lein-ancient/pull/114#2020-02-0820:31chrisnHey, I am trying to upload a jar to brand new group, 'libpython-clj' and I am getting an access denied error. I think this is because stevechan uploaded a libpython-clj jar with no group: https://clojars.org/libpython-clj I can always make up a new group name which is fine or is there a way to address this? I am the original author of https://clojars.org/cnuernber/libpython-clj and we need to expand to a multiple-jar ecosystem to support clj-new.#2020-02-0821:22tcrawleyRight - in the maven ecosystem, the group is required, so clojure tooling and clojars treat foo as foo/foo. You will need to get in touch with stevechan and them add you as a member of the libpython-clj group.#2020-02-1216:54chrisnThanks, it was easier to create a new group entirely that I know I own.#2020-02-1216:55chrisnWhich is I think the most diplomatic pathway. There are a couple minefields for projects right when they get popular and public namespaces are (like slack and clojars) can be one of them. Thankfully in this case it wasn't a troll who was front-running to be rude.#2020-02-1004:03vemvAs a (non-urgent) FYI, clojars deployments have been deploying for me with: 
Could not transfer metadata xxxxx:xxxxxxxx/maven-metadata.xml from/to clojars (): Read timed out
Failed to deploy metadata: Could not transfer metadata xxxxx:xxxxxxxx/maven-metadata.xml from/to clojars (): Read timed out
This is the second day in a row. Can be worked around by retrying#2020-02-1004:44tcrawleyUsually when that happens the deploy actually succeeds. I did some work earlier today to do less during a deploy to prevent this from happening. It should be even less tomorrow evening which I hope will help out with this issue.#2020-02-1004:46vemvYou're right - all my deploys had actually succeed! (but the responsible CI build had failed) Hadn't realised this. Thanks for all the info!#2020-02-1004:51tcrawleyMy pleasure! And just to give more detail - after your client uploads the maven-metadata.xml file, but before the server responds, the server does the following: • it verifies the deploy is valid • it writes the deployed artifacts to Cloudfiles • it writes the deployed artifacts to S3 • until earlier today, it added the deploy to the search index Once that is all done, it responds to your client. So if that takes too long, the client times out. I made indexing async today, and hope to drop writing to Cloudfiles tomorrow (we're in the middle of a transition from Cloudfiles to S3, and have to dual-write for the time being - see https://groups.google.com/d/msg/clojars-maintainers/LvfZMiGTYWg/QxBo7PG3AgAJ for details).#2020-02-1004:51tcrawleyMy pleasure! And just to give more detail - after your client uploads the maven-metadata.xml file, but before the server responds, the server does the following: • it verifies the deploy is valid • it writes the deployed artifacts to Cloudfiles • it writes the deployed artifacts to S3 • until earlier today, it added the deploy to the search index Once that is all done, it responds to your client. So if that takes too long, the client times out. I made indexing async today, and hope to drop writing to Cloudfiles tomorrow (we're in the middle of a transition from Cloudfiles to S3, and have to dual-write for the time being - see https://groups.google.com/d/msg/clojars-maintainers/LvfZMiGTYWg/QxBo7PG3AgAJ for details).#2020-02-1906:40BjaggHi folks, I am trying to create my first clojar. From looking in the logs on the server, I can see all of the artifacts making it there except the maven-metadata.xml - I don't see the request making it to the server for your failed deploys. That makes me think there is a problem at the fastly CDN level and that is what is returning the 400. But when I try it locally with a brand new artifact or a new snapshot version, it succeeds. Will do.#2020-02-2004:21wilkerluciohello, I'm trying to publish a new version of a library, but I'm getting: Could not transfer metadata com.wsscode:pathom/maven-metadata.xml from/to clojars (): Checksum validation failed, expected 9f19c38290c67b3962ccc4445f08e5a69bac0853 but is 78a718e8d7c4d32ed8141f710190f679386eb732#2020-02-2004:22wilkerlucioI did upload another version early and it worked fine, I'm doing it using lein with lein deploy clojars, does someone know how can I fix this? I tried some tutorials like trying to PUT to force update the SHA, but that didn't worked#2020-02-2004:28raaon👋 i've had same maven-metadata.xml checksum issue as reported here and as a workaround i can successfully deploy by setting :checksum :ignore in my :deploy-repositories project.clj config#2020-02-2007:19ambrosebswhat's the equivalent fix for maven?#2020-02-2013:17tcrawley@ambrosebs I don't know what the fix is for maven, but if you are seeing the issue, would you mind sharing the output?#2020-02-2014:24wilkerlucio@atdixon can you send an example of what that looks like? I see vectors and I'm not sure where to put the :checksum :ignore#2020-02-2015:06Jacquesis it just me or is down? getting a 503 on all my clojars packages ...#2020-02-2016:38tcrawleyIt's not down for me - can you give an example of a package that gives you a 503? Are you behind a proxy of some sort?#2020-02-2107:17Jacquesi wasn't behind a proxy, but don't worry, seems to be working now @U06SGCEHJ#2020-02-2016:48Bjagg@wilkerlucio see https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/master/sample.project.clj#L114#2020-02-2016:50Bjagg@ambrosebs see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14350729/why-does-maven-report-checksum-validation-failed-no-checksums-available-from-t/14945261#2020-02-2016:50BjaggCan disable it via an -D option or set it in your POM#2020-02-2018:37wilkerlucio@bjagg hello, I tried using the one at the top level, but it didn't work, and I'm not sure how to configure the clojars in other extended way, because currently all I have is :deploy-repositories [["releases" :clojars]], how do I turn this :clojars into a map to add the :checksum inside of it?#2020-02-2018:51BjaggHere’s what I just used + the checksum bits: 
:deploy-repositories [[ "clojars" {:url ""
                                     :creds :gpg :checksum :ignore}]
                        ["releases" :clojars]
                        ["snapshots" :clojars]]
#2020-02-2018:58wilkerlucio@bjagg that works! thank you so much!#2020-02-2101:23tcrawleyI've identified a couple of possible issues, and have made attempts to address both. I don't think they are related, other than being related to the recent move of the repo from Rackspace Cloudfiles to S3: • maven-metadata.xml checksums being incorrect - this is the issue that @wilkerlucio was seeing. I think there was a failure to upload the sum files from the server -> s3, but I wasn't checking the results of the call, so the code would have considered it always successful. I've modified the s3 client to throw on error so we can see if that happens again • 400 Bad Request responses when trying to deploy - I was able to find 400 responses in Fastly logs, and they were all for maven-metadata.xml files. I suspect this might be related to some custom Fastly configuration we had to set short cache TTLs for the metadata files (and sums). I've removed that configuration and now instead make purge requests against Fastly's API for maven-metadata.xml files (and their checksum files) when a deploy occurs. This is a better approach anyway, since it would make the new metadata files available pretty much immediately instead of having to wait for the 60 second TTL to expire and allows us to cache metadata files that don't change for much longer, which is a cost savings. @bjagg @ambrosebs @atdixon - would y'all mind trying to deploy again at your leisure and see if you see the 400 Bad Request (or any other) error?#2020-02-2101:56ambrosebs@tcrawley just tried again:

#2020-02-2104:30BjaggIPs are different#2020-02-2217:09tcrawley@ambrosebs @bjagg @atdixon I did some more digging but I still haven't figured out the root cause. A summary of what I've found so far, based on log files from 2020-02-20 and 2020-02-21: • The 400s are being returned by the Fastly CDN • It is only on a few GET requests for maven-metadata.xml files (both existing (which should return a 200) and non-existing (which should return a 404)). No other paths are affected. • Only six client IPs were affected out of 8,122 that made GET /.../maven-metadata.xml requests • Only 266 requests were affected out of 107,255 for GET /.../maven-metadata.xml • Those 266 requests were for 54 different maven-metadata.xml paths • There is no common client, OS version, or Java version based on the user-agent strings • There is no common cache host • I have not been able to recreate it Actions taken to remediate: • There was custom configuration in Fastly to override the cache TTL for maven-metadata.xml files. This is the only configuration that would treat those files differently. It was obviated by https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/commit/6c081e809a4c2e0c4ddf5359c2fc858d1cd5dc2b and removed ~ 2020-02-21 01:00 UTC • This didn't resolve the issue immediately, but it's possible the 400s were cached • ~2020-02-22 16:30 UTC all 54 paths that had 400s in the logs were purged from Fastly's cache • It is unknown if this will help with the issue I've captured this in https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/744 as well. Since I just purged all of those paths from Fastly, can y'all test again when you get a chance? I really appreciate your help and your patience.#2020-02-2217:10tcrawleyI'll also analyze the logs again this evening to see how things look (the logs are aggregated every evening from 100s of individual files, so doing analysis before that aggregation occurs is painful)#2020-02-2217:17tcrawleyI also added some more details to that GH issue about the workarounds that y'all have been successful with so far.#2020-02-2218:10ambrosebs@tcrawley wow thanks for such a thorough investigation! tried it again, still same error unfortunately. Reported it to https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/744#2020-02-2218:50tcrawleyThanks for testing @ambrosebs! I just added more logging to Fastly to a service where I can see the logs more easily - would you mind trying again when you have a chance? I'll then see if there are any clues in the extended logs#2020-02-2219:12Bjagg@tcrawley Deploying snapshot worked! Had a checksum error earlier, but that did not occur this last time. Thanks!!#2020-02-2219:33ambrosebs@tcrawley gets a little further! https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/744#issuecomment-589990610#2020-02-2219:34ambrosebsfixed link ^^#2020-02-2219:52tcrawleyThanks @ambrosebs @bjagg! With the additional logging, I also see 400s for maven-metadata.xml.sha1 and .md5 files from your requests. Unfortunately, the logs don't provide any additional insights. I have however enabled request logging on the S3 bucket itself. That log is supposed to include an error reason if the 400 is originating from S3. If y'all could try yet again I would be most appreciative, and I'll check on those logs a bit later.#2020-02-2219:53Bjagg@tcrawley failed with a 400#2020-02-2219:56ambrosebs@tcrawley again: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/744#issuecomment-589992556#2020-02-2222:15tcrawley@ambrosebs @bjagg ok, with S3 logging on, I can see the 400 requests being rejected due to InvalidArgument. The S3 docs for InvalidArgument aren't very helpful, but I did find reference to that being returned if the Authorization header is set, but not to valid AWS credentials. So I added logging for that header, and see it set on the 400 error requests since I enabled it. I then added a rule in fastly to strip that header from the request before passing it to S3. Would y'all be willing to try again?#2020-02-2223:28ambrosebs@tcrawley I think it worked!#2020-02-2223:28ambrosebsI'll paste the output in the issue#2020-02-2223:29ambrosebsthanks @tcrawley!!#2020-02-2223:36Bjagg@tcrawley that works for me!!#2020-02-2223:50tcrawleyAwesome! I'm glad we finally figured it out! I'll update the issue with the details and clean up my mess of logging. Thanks again for your help and patience @ambrosebs @bjagg @atdixon#2020-02-2223:52ambrosebsyou rock @tcrawley thanks so much!#2020-02-2223:54BjaggYeah thank u!#2020-02-2300:07tcrawleyMy pleasure! I updated the issue with the details: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/744#2020-02-2510:33Captain PorcelainHello everyone, this might be a rather stupid question but I'm stuck on it. But that name is just being pulled from the basic auth, so before it gets to the clojars application.#2020-02-2512:03tcrawleyDo you also see org.clojars.captainporcelain as a group under the new account?#2020-02-2512:03tcrawleyBecause having access to the - version really feels like a bug and a security hole#2020-02-2512:05Captain PorcelainYes I can see both.#2020-02-2512:07Captain PorcelainIt may have been created by the jar I've uploaded. I've used it in the pom and didn't change it to the version without - before uploading.#2020-02-2512:49Captain PorcelainIs there a way to delete my first account (captain-porcelain)?#2020-02-2512:50Captain PorcelainAnyways, thank you very much for your help 😃#2020-02-2601:55tcrawleySorry for the late reply, but I've figured it out: • Your first account was called captain-procelain, not captain-porcelain • You pushed to org.clojure.captain-porcelain, not org.clojars.captain-porcelain , so the special user group logic didn't prevent that, since the group name was unclaimed • I went ahead and deleted the captain-procelain user#2020-02-2606:12Captain PorcelainOh my.#2020-02-2606:13Captain PorcelainNow I feel stupid. And in dire need of new glasses#2020-02-2606:13Captain PorcelainThank you for looking into this 😊#2020-02-2611:20tcrawleyNo worries, and my pleasure!#2020-03-0718:00Aaron CummingsI had been using lftp to selectively mirror artifacts from Clojars to an internal repo, but recent changes have broken directory listings (as they are now done with javascript). Sorry for breaking your workflow - we moved the repo to s3 (from Rackspace Cloudfiles) and lost the html index generation. Since it is on s3, you could use aws s3 sync . to synchronize a local copy. I would just ask that you don't run that more than once every 24 hours. You may need aws credentials for that to work, but those credentials wouldn't need rights to that bucket - it's publicly readable.#2020-03-0720:37Aaron CummingsGreat Toby, I'll give that a shot. 	at clojure.lang.RestFn.applyTo(RestFn.java:137)
	at clojure.lang.Var.applyTo(Var.java:705)
	at clojure.main.main(main.java:37)
#2020-03-0821:21tcrawleyDo you see it even trying to find it in clojars? Or just in maven central?#2020-03-0821:23darwinI was unable to figure out what exactly tools deps is doing, I think the message about maven is wrong, it should be trying clojars as well. but doing another deploy using the same scripts worked, so version 1.5.9 is good#2020-03-0821:24darwinbtw. I repeated the same thing, first deploy of 1.5.9 failed with “no checksums provided” and then I fixed the leiningen and deployed again with success, and the deployed file is correct#2020-03-0821:25darwinbtw. this project is not deployed to maven central, and never was#2020-03-0821:26darwinthe strange thing is that 1.5.8 looks good on http://clojars.org via web interface#2020-03-0821:29tcrawleyClojars tries to make deploys atomic. Deploys go to a staging repo, then validation is performed on the deploy to try to confirm it is correct (that's where the no checksums provided for dirac-1.5.8.jar.asc message comes from). If all the validation succeeds, the deploy is then moved in to the real repo. So you can redeploy the same version if it failed. And 1.5.8 seems fine to me - it downloads for me w/o issue. The reason tools.deps is reporting that it can't find it in Maven Central is because it doesn't know where artifacts live, it just asks each repo from its list of repositories in order, and Maven Central is first. If it can't find it in one repo (meaning it got a 404), it will try the next repo in the list. If no repo has it, it will report that it could not find it in the first repo it tried I believe.#2020-03-0821:30tcrawleyIf you rm ~/.m2/repository/binaryage/dirac/1.5.8 and rerun your tools.deps invocation, does it then download it?#2020-03-0821:32darwinno, https://gist.github.com/darwin/7e103d6473f6263dc56baab20227653e#2020-03-0821:32darwinso this works for you?#2020-03-0821:33tcrawleyYep, see my output above in this thread#2020-03-0821:34tcrawleyI don't know much about deps - is there a way to have it print the repos it is using?#2020-03-0821:38darwindon’t know, I didn’t go that deep to look into its sources#2020-03-0821:38darwinso it works for you, so maybe it is just some cache issue, maybe between me and clojars#2020-03-0821:38darwinbecause version 1.5.9 works as expected#2020-03-0821:39darwinso it is not caused by misconfigured tools.deps on my machine#2020-03-0821:40tcrawleyThat's a good point - Fastly does cache 404s, so it's possible the edge node that is serving you has cached that 1.5.8 does not exist, but the one serving me did not. That means that 1.5.8 should work for you in < 24 hours, since that's the TTL#2020-03-0821:40darwinok, let’s wait, I will try it again tomorrow and report back#2020-03-0821:41darwinthanks for your help#2020-03-0821:41tcrawleyMy pleasure#2020-03-1014:32Alex Miller (Clojure team)Re "If no repo has it, it will report that it could not find it in the first repo it tried I believe." this is correct. If there are multiple failures, tools.deps reports the first one (which repo that is is kind of arbitrary), but really that typically means it was not able to get from any repo.#2020-03-1014:33Alex Miller (Clojure team)this is hard to "fix" as there's no way to know which repo it was supposed to have been downloaded from. you could report all, but in some cases (multiple repos configured), you would see a flood of errors which would not actually give you any additional info.#2020-03-1014:36darwinhmm, the message could be general without mentioning a repo or print something like “tried central (…) and 2 others” this way it is quite misleading, because I spent quite some time fishing in my config files whether clojars is really configured as my secondary repo#2020-03-1014:39darwinI ended up hardcoding :mvn/repos in my deps.edn just to be sure, but I couldn’t force their order to really confirm that clojars was actually tried#2020-03-1014:43Alex Miller (Clojure team)these messages are just coming out of maven and are only one of many errors that could be reported (differing only in message). doing what you just suggest means basically parsing and analyzing error message strings emitted from maven#2020-03-1014:44darwinah, nevermind, I see#2020-03-1014:45Alex Miller (Clojure team)if you use the mvn tool itself, I think it makes similar choices iirc#2020-03-1014:03darwin@tcrawley I just tried the clojure -Srepro -Sdeps '{:deps {binaryage/dirac {:mvn/version "1.5.8"} org.clojure/clojurescript {:mvn/version "RELEASE"} clj-logging-config {:mvn/version "1.9.12"}}}' -m dirac.main again on the same machine and it works now. so this likely confirms that it was a caching issue#2020-03-1108:00slipsetA couple of cents worth of info. OK, but how should I store it and use it?#2020-05-1418:43tcrawleyHi @oskarkv - the deploy tokens are a beta feature that hasn't been widely announced or documented yet, sorry about that. You should use it in place of a password when deploying to clojars.#2020-05-1418:58oskarkv@tcrawley So I should replace the password string with it?#2020-05-1419:00tcrawleycorrect!#2020-05-1419:00oskarkvOK, thanks!#2020-05-1419:00tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2020-05-1806:00slipsetBTW, just updated the deps-deploy readme to reflect this https://github.com/slipset/deps-deploy/blob/master/README.md#2020-06-0417:14pithylessAny ideas why this may be happening?

Clojars is such a solid and stable silent partner in everyday development, I never even considered it might be a caching issue until I ruled everything else out. 🙂#2020-06-0417:26tcrawleyheh#2020-06-2405:52samratHi, I am getting 503's when fetching deps: 
Could not transfer artifact lambdaisland:tools.namespace:jar:0.0-237 from/to clojars (): Failed to transfer file: . Return code is: 503 , ReasonPhrase:Backend unavailable, connection timeout.
#2020-06-2518:36tcrawleyWhere are you located geographically? We've had a few reports of this and I wonder if it is related to where a Fastly edge node is and therefore which s3 endpoint it is using.#2020-06-2508:19eskosIs it possible to attach custom project metadata to clojars publish? I’d want to tag versioning scheme, as it seems break versioning is gaining traction, and some people use date of release, while SemVer is what Maven natively just assumes, even though Maven’s versioning is way older than the SemVer spec. Reason for this is that using tools such as lein ancient would need this metadata to be able to work correctly, as it simply expects SemVer with Maven’s snapshot/qualified additions.#2020-06-2518:45tcrawleyThere's no direct way to attach metadata since we are built on top of maven poms which aren't really extensible. A few options I've thought about for something like this are: • setting properties in the pom file - those are intended to be used to set system properties at runtime, but could be abused to store metadata • adding a optional metadata file that can be deployed alongside an artifact. It would use maven's classifier system, so wouldn't custom deployment machinery. It would require lein/whatever changes or plugins though #2020-06-2606:47eskosHmmh. So it would have to be totally custom, somewhat annoying…#2020-06-2606:47eskosFWIW, the same problem is solved by eg. Nexus and Artifactory by providing an entirely separate system (think property files with RGB LEDs or whatever the cool kids nowadays do to pimp out their stuff…)#2020-06-2606:49eskosI guess that would mean that in order to be able to get this, Clojure community would need to agree on project metadata descriptor which would work from sensible defaults to overridable logic to keep backwards compatibility at bay and I shudder at the thought of that, although it probably would be the most useful thing in long run…I definitely am not the person to do so, but thinking out loud the whole deps.edn effort could also benefit from this.#2020-06-2606:49eskosThanks anyways! 🙂 Have to let this thought simmer a bit longer.#2020-06-2813:12tcrawleyFYI: a deploy token is now required to deploy to Clojars. See https://groups.google.com/d/msg/clojure/UXx3ko0Ne-w/VnJA4eu6AQAJ for details. Thanks!#2020-06-3015:44Lone RangerHi there! I believe that the aggregation mechanism for clojars is down. Sending juxt/crux-http-server/maven-metadata.xml (1k) to 
Could not transfer metadata juxt:crux-http-server/maven-metadata.xml from/to clojars (): Access denied to: , ReasonPhrase: Forbidden - S3 request failed.
Failed to deploy metadata: Could not transfer metadata juxt:crux-http-server/maven-metadata.xml from/to clojars (): Access denied to: , ReasonPhrase: Forbidden - S3 request failed
#2020-07-2412:25tcrawleyThis might me an intermittent failure that was cached by fastly - that looks like your client is trying to read the file. What do you see if you visit https://repo.clojars.org/juxt/crux-http-server/maven-metadata.xml in a browser?#2020-07-2412:25tcrawleyI see the correct file, but I would be hitting a different fastly node.#2020-07-2412:50jarohenmm, I see what looks like a valid maven-metadata.xml#2020-07-2412:51jarohenI'll give it another go, it's been a couple of hours#2020-07-2412:53tcrawleyok, let me know how it goes. I suspected this was a read issue because we only write to s3 at the very end, but realize now that "the very end" is when you upload the maven-metadata.xml file - that's the signal to finalize the deploy. So the s3 failure could be on any artifact that is part of the deploy, not just the metadata file (not that it matters here).#2020-07-2412:54jarohenAh, ok, thanks#2020-07-2412:56jarohenI've just tried to redeploy a previous version (as the same snapshot) and that went through ok, but coming back to current version still fails. One difference is that our JAR's got bigger - it's gone from around 2MB to around 6MB. Do you know if there's a file size limit? (I'll look into the issue of the larger JAR separately 🙂)#2020-07-2412:58tcrawleyThere is a limit, but I'm not sure what it is atm. But it is enforced by nginx, so we should get a failure earlier in that case. I'll take a look at the logs to see if there is anything more useful there#2020-07-2412:59jarohenThanks 🙂#2020-07-2413:02tcrawleyWell, nothing helpful there, just :message "S3 request failed" - no exception logged and no exception sent to sentry :(#2020-07-2413:06jarohenAh, thanks for checking 🙂#2020-07-2413:06tcrawleyI'm adding better error reporting now, should be just a few minutes#2020-07-2413:07jarohenFile size is looking a likely culprit at the moment, seems consistently fine with the smaller (2MB) JAR, consistently failing with the larger (6MB) JAR#2020-07-2413:30tcrawleyI just deployed a change that should log the exception, so let me know if you still see the issue after figuring out the jar size and I'll take a look#2020-07-2918:28Ludger SolbachI'd like to deploy a jar on clojars under the groupId "org.soulspace.clj" but I get an Access denied/Forbidden. http://soulspace.org is my personal domain.#2020-07-2918:30Ludger SolbachIs there something I've overlooked? Thanks for the report!#2020-09-0418:04dominicmJust as a thank you: I deployed something recently and clojars gave me the prompt to stop using my password and it was really useful. Thank you!#2020-09-0418:15tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2020-10-0705:09didibusRealized after the fact there is a Clojars channel#2020-10-0707:49didibusOkay, my best idea to move forward with something of that sort would be that when someone pushes to Clojars and the groupId doesn't already exists, Clojars would: If groupId is a reverse domain like org.foo Check that the domain http://foo.org has TXT DNS header for http://_clojars.foo.org with value equal to org.foo. If check fails, refuse to create the group. Else if it has a groupId like github-foo Check that the github user foo has a public repo called _clojars with a readme file that contains the value github-foo. If check fails, refuse to create the group. Else proceed to create the group as current assuming other validation pass.#2020-10-0707:49didibusSimilar things could be added for gitlab-foo and bitbucket-foo etc.#2020-10-0707:50didibusNow that way, going forward, I know that if I depend on a lib with a groupId that is a reverse domain or a github-foo like format, that the origin was verified and I can trust it comes from the real domain owner or the real repo owner on GitHub.#2020-10-0712:37Alex Miller (Clojure team)Just as a point of comparison, with maven central a human is involved in granting access to new groupids (but I have no idea what level of rigor is involved)#2020-10-0712:40tcrawleyYou can see an example of the maven central verification process here: https://issues.sonatype.org/browse/OSSRH-60335#2020-10-0712:40tcrawleyIt is similar to what is proposed above, but with human verification#2020-10-0712:42tcrawleyClojars came about in part as push back to the maven central verification requirements (though, at the time, I think central didn't support com.github.username groups). If we want to move towards verified groups, I think we should push folks to deploy to maven central instead of modifying Clojars to do the same thing#2020-10-0712:44tcrawleyReleasing to central is a bit more painful, given that deploys go to a staging repo then have to be released manually. But there is mvn tooling to to that automatically, and it wouldn't be difficult to build a lein/`boot` /whatever plugin to do that (if they don't already exist)#2020-10-0712:48Alex Miller (Clojure team)Actually, it is fairly difficult due to gpg signing#2020-10-0712:48tcrawleyAh, good point#2020-10-0712:49tcrawleySince gpg signing isn't that useful, let's just generate a new gpg key automatically for every deploy :)#2020-10-0717:20didibusHum, the manual process is also painful. If the above is automated, I can in 5min have a new groupId for my open source project pushed to Clojars. But with Maven Central it takes a few days of turnaround#2020-10-0717:20tcrawleyThat's definitely true.#2020-10-0717:21tcrawleyI'm also considering the effort to build & maintain that system in Clojars#2020-10-0717:22didibusYa that's a very fair consideration.#2020-10-0717:23Alex Miller (Clojure team)a) you should ideally only have 1 (or small number of) groupIDs#2020-10-0717:23Alex Miller (Clojure team)b) and if a, ~day turnaround is no big deal#2020-10-0717:24Alex Miller (Clojure team)but I do think the automated path via dns is a reasonable automated check and certainly in line with what others things do#2020-10-0717:31didibusIt seems Maven established a different convention for github? And they do com.github.user where as right now in the Clojure community I think I saw recommendation for github-user. I think I like the latter better because of the possibility for github to want to own the com.github groupId for their own projects. But I can see an argument for both#2020-10-0717:43Alex Miller (Clojure team)I'm not familiar with the Maven convention if there is one#2020-10-0717:43Alex Miller (Clojure team)the latter recommendation was due to not wanting to stomp on github's own "space"#2020-10-0717:49Alex Miller (Clojure team)and to suggest ways to use other identities as a means of borrowing ownership: twitter-puredanger, gitlab-foo, etc#2020-10-0720:39didibusI'm just going off from that link, seems they approved the creation of groupId com.github.user once the person proved they owned the repo under that user in GitHub. But I like the identityprovider-user approach personally for the same reason that you can't think that's a github published repo#2020-10-0720:42Alex Miller (Clojure team)ah I see they do have an example at https://central.sonatype.org/pages/choosing-your-coordinates.html#2020-10-0720:42Alex Miller (Clojure team)I never saw that before#2020-10-0720:43Alex Miller (Clojure team)seems like there are a lot of those out there https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/io/github/#2020-10-0720:44Alex Miller (Clojure team)seems good to me :)#2020-10-1009:22wilkerluciohello, I'm trying to deploy a library, but getting some S3 error:

So that would imply that they are using a token created for another user.#2020-10-1614:45tcrawleyThey need to create a token under their own account and use that. Or use the username of the account where the token was created (`sentry`?)#2020-10-1614:46dharriganThank you, I shall pass that along. Hopefully they can sort it 🙂#2020-10-1614:52dharrigandone! they were using the wrong username!!!#2020-10-1614:52dharriganthank you @U06SGCEHJ#2020-10-1614:52dharrigan#2020-10-1614:52dharriganin all it's glory#2020-10-1614:54tcrawleyGreat! A brief search of the source code suggests it is read, but is it used for anything (i.e., can it be left out without affecting the information/processing of the library for the library page?)#2020-12-2314:45tcrawleyThe tag is only used to display this output I believe, and it is left off if the tag is missing. So you shouldn't need to include it.#2020-12-2314:51dharriganthank you#2020-12-2314:51tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2021-01-2718:35Shantanu KumarHi, what could be the reason for this deployment error?

From looking at the logs, it looks like you trying to deploy a version that clojars thinks already exists, and that should give you a message like redeploying non-snapshots is not allowed (see ) , but it easily gets lost in the other noise from the client deploy machinery#2021-01-2719:08Shantanu Kumar@U06SGCEHJ Here’s the complete output:

#2021-01-2719:10Shantanu KumarThis particular (non-SNAPSHOT) version is not on Clojars.#2021-01-2719:11tcrawleyWas that from the first deploy attempt or the subsequent ones? I can see the first deploy mostly succeeded, but then aborted due to a 500 error from S3. From looking at the code, it looks like that would leave it in a state where clojars thinks it is deployed, but it really isn't. Let me see what I can do.#2021-01-2719:12Shantanu KumarThe first deploy failed, then I retried few times that also failed.#2021-01-2719:13tcrawleyThat agrees with what I see in the logs. I would have expected all deploys after the first to tell you that you can't redeploy a non-snapshot. If it didn't show that, that's a bug.#2021-01-2719:15tcrawleyI made a change on the server, can you try again now?#2021-01-2719:17Shantanu Kumar@U06SGCEHJ Succeeded this time, thanks!#2021-01-2719:17tcrawleyGreat! My pleasure!#2021-01-2719:18tcrawleyAnd just to be clear - you didn't see the "redeploying non-snapshots is not allowed" message on any of the deploy attempts?#2021-01-2719:27Shantanu KumarNo, I didn’t.#2021-01-2719:27tcrawleyThanks for confirming, I'll create an issue for that and investigate it further.#2021-01-2718:36Shantanu KumarThe JAR file size is 24KB.#2021-02-1216:32Alex Miller (Clojure team)https://blog.sonatype.com/why-namespacing-matters-in-public-open-source-repositories#2021-02-1321:58tcrawleyI've been thinking about this for a bit. I don't think it would be too difficult/onerous to move to a safer model. I hope to have time to write up a proposal for discussion this weekend.#2021-02-1621:39dominicmThe key part is the validation right?#2021-02-1621:42dominicmI suppose some easy validations for Clojars without impeding users too much would be GH OAuth, etc.#2021-02-1621:47dominicmThe sonatype process is a little onerous, requiring the creation of jira tickets (and we know how much clojurists hate jira) so I think clojars could automate that.#2021-02-1622:11tcrawleyWell, I didn't have a chance to write up my thoughts, but they are, roughly: This is indeed a validation problem - we want to validate group names. • org.clojars.<clojars-username> groups - we don't have to do anything here, since we are already validating these • com.github.<github-username> groups - validating these would be straightforward since we already have "Log in with GitHub". We would just need to add some logic there, then deny deploys to those groups until someone that is group owner (or the group creator, if a push will create the group) logs in via GitHub with that username • other reverse-hostname groups - We could validate these automatically with a TXT record. I think initially I would prefer doing so manually with folks filing GH issues, since that would let us see what validation methods work for folks, and wouldn't require as much upfront implementation (so could be released sooner - my availability to work on Clojars is essentially a small amount of time on the weekends ATM) • That leaves non-reverse-hostname groups - these are (generally) less likely to shadow internal artifacts, especially when the group and artifact name are the same (`cheshire/cheshire` , hiccup/hiccup, etc). These require a bit of thought on how to validate. We could: ◦ Allow deployment to continue to existing ones, but don't allow new ones to be created, pushing folks to use reverse-hostname groups ◦ Allow them to be created unvalidated. This isn't a great option, since it would still allow potential shadowing, and would push more folks to using these types of groups since reverse-hostname groups now require validation, and it would be good for us to go the other way as a community. An open question is do we disallow all deploys to an unvalidated group? Or just forbid creation of new artifacts until validation? Or just disallow new group creation until validation? Another easier (implementation-wise) but more painful (for the community) option is to make clojars read-only, and have folks switch to deploying to OSSRH. That would require lots more work from library maintainers, and would change the names of almost everything, so probably isn't a great option. But it would move us to a more vetted/trusted model, and would take some of the burden of maintaining our own package system off of me/the community. That's my $0.02 currently. I would love feedback on this from anyone interested. I can take the discussion here and move it to: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/discussions later cc: @U051KLSJF#2021-02-1622:19Alex Miller (Clojure team)personally, I'd like to add friction/resistance to adding new foo/foo names and do whatever we can to encourage either hostname (or copyright/trademark "ownership") or conferred identity via hosts like github#2021-02-1622:20tcrawleyI agree#2021-02-1622:20Alex Miller (Clojure team)I do not think we need or want to push people to OSSRH, it really is significantly more onerous due to several rules#2021-02-1622:21Alex Miller (Clojure team)not just signing, but silly things for clojurians like source/javadocs#2021-02-1622:21tcrawleyI agree there as well, but wanted to present it because it is an option#2021-02-1622:30tcrawleyI have moved this discussion to https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/discussions/777. Let's continue it there if that works for folks#2021-02-1700:13Alex Miller (Clojure team)I appreciate your work on this...#2021-02-1701:31tcrawleyMy pleasure!#2021-02-2301:18tcrawleyI've put forth a group verification proposal that I would like feedback on: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/discussions/777#discussioncomment-395962#2021-02-1216:32Alex Miller (Clojure team)^^ food for serious thought#2021-02-1622:30tcrawleyI have moved this discussion to https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/discussions/777. Let's continue it there if that works for folks#2021-02-2301:18tcrawleyI've put forth a group verification proposal that I would like feedback on: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/discussions/777#discussioncomment-395962#2021-02-2118:29seancorfieldPurely FYI, yesterday I was trying to deploy a new release of depstar and it was failing from my WSL2 (Ubuntu) machine but succeeding from my Mac -- both times using the same version of deps-deploy. I ran a bit of debugging from WSL2 and saw this: 
{:tag :a, :attrs {:href "/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection", :class "__cf_email__", :data-cfemail "295a4c48474a696d6c7a627d6679041a19606a681e1f"}, :content ("[email protected]")}
Obviously, today that is fine -- but it looks like the new certificate was applied to http://clojars.org a bit early? I guess I'm just surprised why that would error out on some systems but not on others. Here's the error I ran into: 
{:tag :a, :attrs {:href "/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection", :class "__cf_email__", :data-cfemail "3f4c5a5e515c7f7b7a6c746b706f120c0f767c7e0809"}, :content ("[email protected]")}
#2021-02-2119:05tcrawleyInteresting - what time (UTC) was it when you saw the failure Sean? We use AWS's automated certificate management, and it handles creating and applying the new certs for us. Looking at the AWS console, it claims that the cert was created at 2021-02-21T00:28:31UTC and applied it at 2021-02-21T00:29:13UTC, so I would only expect a client to complain if it thought the current time was before that#2021-02-2120:03seancorfield"Saturday afternoon Pacific time" is about as close as I can be on that. I just noticed that WSL2 is reporting a time that is earlier than the system clock so it has drifted out of sync (I've had my WSL2 running for a long time). It may well have drifted far enough that WSL2 didn't think midnight UTC had been reached... interesting...#2021-02-2120:04seancorfieldHmm, restarted it and it still is behind the system time. OK, will research how/why that happens.#2021-02-2120:11seancorfieldhttps://tomssl.com/fixing-clock-drift-in-wsl2-using-windows-terminal/ -- oh well, TIL!#2021-02-2120:12tcrawleyGlad you got it figured out!#2021-02-2120:14seancorfieldThis (clojars deploy) was the first time I'd ever noticed the issue -- and it was hours off when I actually checked it! 🙂 Sorry for the noise, but your response pointed me in the right direction!#2021-02-2120:17tcrawleyYou just go lucky with the yearly cert rotation :)#2021-02-2319:48seancorfield@tcrawley Would you encourage project authors to actively start switching to a group ID of com.github.<username> for publishing artifacts at this point?#2021-02-2400:23tcrawleyI'd like to write up an announcement about the verification plan and timeline first, just so we have a place to point folks to as word of the changes percolate through the community. I'll try to get that out this weekend.#2021-02-2401:20seancorfieldSounds good! I won't update my READMEs or clj-new until after that is up.#2021-02-2401:27tcrawleyThanks!#2021-02-2411:48borkdude@tcrawley food for thought (in screenshot, conversation from #tools-deps) https://github.com/borkdude/deps-infer#2021-02-2413:14borkdude@tcrawley I think for the purpose of libs like these, it would be super awesome if clojars had some kind of index of jars + the list of files in each jar, as EDN, or transit, which refreshed every so often (daily, weekly, monthly)#2021-02-2414:15tcrawleyI think that would be great! I'm focused on adding group validation currently, but we could tackle this afterward. Do you have code already that will generate the index for a single jar?#2021-02-2414:17borkdude@tcrawley Yeah, this code is in https://github.com/borkdude/deps-infer We could work on this together if you want. The part I do not control is the "ops" side, but I can write the "script" that produces the index from a dir of jars#2021-02-2414:22tcrawleyA script to processes a sparse maven repo dir would do the trick. "sparse" meaning it is in the correct shape (`group-name/artfact-name/0.1.0/artifact-name-0.1.0.jar`), but has no pom files. The repo is in s3, but we sync down all of the jar files nightly in order to generate the maven-style indexes for tooling, and could generate this index as part of that process.#2021-02-2414:24tcrawleyWe could then upload these ns indexes to s3 alongside the feeds/jar lists: https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Data#list-of-jars-and-versions-in-leiningen-syntax#2021-02-2414:27borkdudeSounds excellent#2021-02-2415:06borkdude@tcrawley Right now I have some code which walks over a dir with .jar files and produces one huge map:

   :group-id "venantius",

#2021-02-2415:07borkdudePerhaps it would be better to partition this into multiple files#2021-02-2415:08borkdudeFor my local .m2 dir the file is 130822 lines long#2021-02-2415:10borkdude@tcrawley I have this code here: https://github.com/borkdude/deps-infer/blob/main/src/deps_infer/clojars.clj It prints to stdout. You can run it with clojure -M -m deps-infer.clojars > /tmp/index.edn#2021-02-2415:11borkdudeThis file takes 200ms to parse to EDN on my machine which is still quite ok#2021-02-2415:11borkdudeBut for the entire clojars it might get a little bit bloated#2021-02-2415:57borkdudeYou can change the location of the dir it scans for .jar files with --repo#2021-02-2415:59tcrawleyThanks! I'll see if I can find some time today to kick this off on the server to see how long it takes and how large of a file it produces.#2021-02-2416:01borkdudeI produced both an .edn and .transit file and zipped both, here's how it looks on my machine: 
$ ls -la /tmp/index*
-rw-r--r--  1 borkdude  wheel  4363922 Feb 24 16:07 /tmp/index.edn
-rw-r--r--  1 borkdude  wheel   214482 Feb 24 17:00 /tmp/index.edn.zip
-rw-r--r--  1 borkdude  wheel  3594066 Feb 24 16:59 /tmp/index.transit.json
-rw-r--r--  1 borkdude  wheel   393184 Feb 24 17:01 /tmp/index.transit.zip
Funnily enough, the zipped edn looks better than the zipped transit.#2021-02-2513:43tcrawleyI tried to run it on the repo cached on the server last night, but realized my recollection of how we build the maven index was wrong - we pull down the poms, not the jars for indexing :( However, I think we could: • pull down the jars once and index those, then store the index in s3 • index new jars as they are deployed, then merge with the existing index This should work since existing releases are immutable. We could also store the index as many timestamped files - that would allow clients to be able to cache the index, pulling down new files and merging them. I suspect the full index file will be pretty large.#2021-02-2513:46borkdudeyeah, those are good ideas#2021-02-2513:47borkdudeI like the second idea#2021-02-2513:47borkdudethen we can just pull only the latest files#2021-02-2513:52tcrawleyGood deal. We should probably open an issue at https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/new/choose and continue this discussion there#2021-02-2513:55borkdudehttps://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/793#2021-02-2513:55tcrawleyThanks!#2021-02-2709:19borkdudeI think it might be better to have one file per namespace actually, since the amount of namespaces to check is usually little and downloading the entire index would be wasteful in that case. Just one http request per namespace would be ideal.#2021-02-2709:19borkdudeIf you agree, I can change the code to produce those files#2021-02-2514:53Darrick WiebeHi all, sorry to burst in with a problem, but I'm trying to push a repo and it's not being accepted. Is xn--lgc/pure-conditioning an invalid name? The error I'm getting is 
Could not transfer artifact xn--lgc:pure-conditioning:jar:0.1.0 from/to clojars (): Failed to transfer file  with status code 401
#2021-02-2514:54Darrick WiebeThe name is because it's related to my domain: http://www.xn--lgc.com/pure-conditioning#2021-02-2514:54Darrick Wiebeie. https://www.૯.com/pure-conditioning/#2021-02-2514:59tcrawleyIt is being rejected because you are deploying with a password instead of a deploy token. See https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Deploy-Tokens. We used to be able to tell you that when the deploy failed, but can no longer due to https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/issues/774 Also, if this is a new group you are creating, I'd recommend using com.xn--lgc instead. We're going to soon move to requiring new groups to be reverse-domain based and verified, so doing so now would put you ahead of the game.#2021-02-2515:00Darrick WiebeOk, thanks very much. I made a token and was surprised when lein deploy didn't ask me for it.#2021-02-2602:14rwstaunerre: > Also, if this is a new group you are creating, I'd recommend using `com.xn--lgc` instead. We're going to soon move to requiring new groups to be reverse-domain based and verified, so doing so now would put you ahead of the game. what is the recommendation for a new project? com.foo.project/project or com.foo/project ?#2021-02-2602:27seancorfieldif it's a company project, com.companyname/the-project if it's a personal project, I'd probably lean to com.github.username/the-project given this guidance.#2021-02-2602:28seancorfieldOr if you have your own domain that could be easily verified, something like org.mysite/the-project#2021-02-2602:31seancorfieldAnd remember that your namespaces don't have to follow the group/artifact but your top-level namespace segment should be globally unique if you plan to publish it.#2021-02-2610:13aratareHi there. I'm currently struggling with trying to upload my JAR to Clojars. However I think there's something wanky with how I'm setting up GPG. So I've created a key pair, published it to openkey and signed credentials.clj with it. Is there an additional step where I have to upload the public key to Clojars itself? I believe the issue is you are using your email address instead of your username - deploying with an email address isn't supported. Let me know if you are still having issues after that change.#2021-02-2613:59aratareHi @U06SGCEHJ. It's working perfectly now! Thank you for making my day 😄#2021-02-2613:59tcrawleyMy pleasure! Glad we figured it out.#2021-02-2613:33tcrawley@clj149 as far as com.foo.project/project vs com.foo/project goes - that's up to you; both will be supported from a group verification perspective. I would personally only do com.foo.project as a group if the project was an umbrella for multiple libraries: com.foo.quibble/routing, com.foo.quibble/rendering, etc.#2021-02-2614:33rwstaunerThanks, that sounds good to me.#2021-03-0104:07rwstaunerto be clear... is project/project (groupId == artifactId) discouraged, now?#2021-03-0104:17seancorfield@clj149 That has pretty much always been bad, yes, but now it is really discouraged.#2021-03-0104:18seancorfieldIt's like foo.core -- Leiningen's default -- has always been a terrible idea too 🙂#2021-03-0104:41seancorfieldYour GH username is rwstauner so your best bet is com.github.rwstauner/project or io.github.rwstauner/project#2021-03-0113:53tcrawley@clj149 @seancorfield correct - project/project will soon not be an option for new projects. See https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Verified-Group-Names for how we will handle groups in the future, along with a release timeline for these changes.#2021-03-0116:05rwstaunerthanks, i was hoping there was new documentation 🙂#2021-03-0116:22tcrawleyMy pleasure! That documentation just appeared yesterday - you're on the cutting edge!#2021-03-0118:51seancorfield@tcrawley So I can go ahead with my changes to depstar and clj-new now there is a wiki page to point folks to? 🙂#2021-03-0118:55tcrawleyYes indeed, thanks!#2021-03-0119:07seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/clj-new/issues/51 and https://github.com/seancorfield/depstar/issues/70 -- in case you have any feedback before I start implementing them.#2021-03-0119:23tcrawleyThanks! I'll try to take a look this evening#2021-03-0203:49seancorfield@tcrawley Has there been a public announcement about the policy change?#2021-03-0203:53seancorfieldI see there's a Twitter account for @clojars but it hasn't tweeted in three years...#2021-03-0212:03tcrawley@seancorfield Yep! I announced it yesterday morning: https://groups.google.com/g/clojure/c/cWG-V_4uv90/m/PnT-rJ6uFQAJ I don't use Twitter much - I'll see if I still have the password for the clojars account#2021-03-0212:10tcrawleyTweeted!#2021-03-0217:20seancorfieldRT'd. Will try to get the new versions of clj-new and depstar out this week with the "encouragement" to switch to VGNs.#2021-03-0218:18tcrawleyThanks Sean!#2021-03-0218:25seancorfield@tcrawley As I'm updating the clj-new README, it occurred to me that there's a specific category of projects that will fall foul of the new policy: templates for Leiningen, Boot, and the CLI all assume that lein new foobar myapp will pull in foobar/lein-template from a repo and use that. I guess those will need to change to things like com.luminusweb/lein-template in the future, rather than just luminus/lein-template, and then users will have to do lein new com.luminusweb myapp instead. [I know that #2021-03-0218:27tcrawleyThat's a great point that I hadn't considered, thanks for bringing it up. I should add a FAQ entry for that, and will create an issue to update docs that talk about creating templates.#2021-03-0218:29seancorfieldSince clj-new also covers that, I'll make it clear that template names should be <vgn>/clj-template for CLI templates, and I'll make sure that new template projects created by clj-new follow that pattern.#2021-03-0218:44tcrawleyThanks!#2021-03-0222:19seancorfieldHaving looked at a few more templates in the wild, I realized that <vgn>/clj-template won't work, so I've opened issues in the Leiningen, Boot New, and clj-new repos to discuss with other tool maintainers. I think that allowing template names to be qualified -- and hence VGN-compliant -- doesn't add much complexity to any of the tooling, so you could have com.luminusweb/starter as a template name and we'd look for com.luminusweb/starter.lein-template etc.#2021-03-0222:36tcrawleyThanks for taking that on. Let me know if I can help. That proposal sounds like it would work to me#2021-03-0218:46tcrawleyIt looks like we are having DNS issues with http://clojars.org. Investigating now#2021-03-0218:47aratareWas about to post a question because I saw 503 😅 Glad you're on top of it.#2021-03-0218:47tcrawleyIt looks like it is an issue with DNSimple: https://dnsimple.statuspage.io/#2021-03-0219:37tcrawleyhttp://clojars.org is now resolving for me, so we may be back up.#2021-03-0220:09seancorfieldThe README for clj-new has been overhauled to mention/encourage the use of verified group names (along with some code changes so the default behavior is compliant with the new policy) -- feedback welcome: https://github.com/seancorfield/clj-new (note: I haven't quite figured out what to do about clj-template's yet so those sections are still a WIP). I've also updated the README for depstar: https://github.com/seancorfield/depstar -- and the next version will warn if :group-id does not look like a reverse domain name. I'll also switch the group for both of those libraries to com.github.seancorfield but double-publish them to the seancorfield group for a while for continuity.#2021-03-0308:36slipsetWould it be nice to add a “Verfied”-badge to the artifacts which come from, well, verified sources?#2021-03-0310:05tcrawleyYep! #2021-03-0518:58tcrawleyHow are you deploying? With that, I think you would want to do lein deploy releases#2021-03-0723:42tcrawleyHowdy folks! An update on the progress of the group verification work: • net.clojars.<username> groups are now available to all • net|org.clojars.<username> groups are automatically verified • logging in via GitHub now auto-verifies (and claims, if they don't already exist) com|io.github.<gh-username> • badges marking verified groups are now sprinkled throughout the app (see screenshots below) Next up I'll be working on adding "log in via GitLab" and the corresponding groups for that.#2021-03-0723:50seancorfieldThank you, @tcrawley! I believe they are unordered, so would default to ordered by db id/creation. It would be straightforward to remedy that though. I'll look now.#2021-03-0800:08tcrawleyDone - they are now sorted by name. I didn't group by verified.
